DOC.HEAD: Proposed Techs' Contract Goes to Union Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Peecook cq in 6th graf
DOC.TEXT: Communications workers at The Associated Press will vote on a tentative contract agreement that management called fair but union leaders said is inadequate. The AP announced Saturday that it and Local 1314 of the Communication Workers of America had reached a tentative agreement on a contract calling for a ``managed care'' approach to control the cost of the medical plan. The agreement also calls for a $23.50 weekly increase in top-scale technician salaries in the first year and a $24 weekly boost in the second, raising the top-scale technician salary to $612 in 1991. Similar percentage increases were proposed for all other job classifications. ``The economic package is fair and the proposals are reasonable,'' D. Byron Yake, AP's director of human resources, said Sunday. Yake said he thought the union membership would approve the pact ``when they hear details of the package.'' Leaders of the CWA local agreed to submit the proposed contract to their 300 members for a vote but said they would recommend that it be rejected. Jim Peecook, president of the union local, said the health plan proposals represented ``a severe loss to those employees and their families.'' He also said the proposed increase in pension benefits was inadequate. ``Since they feel that it's a fair, generous and equitable solution and we do not, we're going to go through the democratic process,'' Peecook said. ``We'll be putting out a full description of the changes along with a recommendation to reject the proposals.'' Terms of the present contract were extended until July 2 pending the vote, the AP said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Three in Highway Rock-Throwing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to CORRECT that rocks and bricks thrown from shoulder of interstate, sted overpass; two 18-year-olds charged with assault with intent to murder, sted assault and battery, details. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: State police said they arrested three youths Saturday who were believed responsible for throwing rocks and bricks from the shoulder of an interstate last weekend, critically injuring a 15-year-old girl. John Burgess, 18, of Forest Heights and Maurice Ford, 18, of this District of Columbia suburb were arrested with a 17-year-old boy after the incident early last Sunday, police said. Seven people were injured by the bricks and rocks, some weighing up to 10 pounds, that were hurled from a shoulder of the Capital Beltway. The beltway passes through both Maryland and Virginia suburbs of the nation's capital. Among the victims was a 15-year-old Hagerstown, Md., girl, who remained in critical condition at Maryland Hospital Center on Saturday night. She was riding in one of the vehicles when a rock crashed through the windshield. Between 25 and 30 vehicles were struck by the objects. Maryland State Police spokesman Chuck Jackson said the two 18-year-olds were each charged with assault with intent to murder and malicious destruction of property. He said charges against the juvenile had yet to be determined. Investigators were not sure of a motive, but state police Capt. John Hughes said the incident likely was a ``spur of the moment type of thing.'' The two 18-year-olds graduated Friday from Oxon High School.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy Lieutenant Slain In Apparent Robbery, Police Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. Navy lieutenant slain in robbery attempt and provincial governor threatening military action to free kidnapped Japanese aid worker. Pickup 5th graf pvs: Philippine police ...
DOC.TEXT: Two masked men fatally stabbed a U.S. Navy lieutenant in his home near the Subic Bay Naval Base in an apparent robbery, police said Sunday. U.S. officials ordered all personnel restricted to the naval base immediately following the Saturday night attack, but lifted the restrictions Sunday after determining the killing was not politically motivated. Police identified the stabbing victim as Lt. Richard Brown, 33, who was assigned to the Navy Supply Depot at the base. No home town was given for the victim. Meanwhile, hundreds of Filipino troops drove through Communist-held neighborhoods in the city of Angeles near the U.S.-run Clark Air Base Saturday in a show of force after U.S. troops were restricted to the garrison for security reasons. The Philippine military also warned foreign aid workers to watch for terrorism. Five days ago, guerrillas suspected of belonging to the New People's Army kidnapped a Japanese development official on the central island of Negros. The provincial governor of Negros Occidental province on Sunday threatened military action to free the Japanese aid worker unless his abductors make contact with authorities soon. Security has been stepped up around Subic, Clark and four other U.S. bases following the killing of three American servicemen in the past month. In Olongapo, the base town near Subic, police said Brown was having a manicure in his apartment when the two assailants forced their way in around 10:45 p.m. Saturday. The assailants, whose faces were covered with T-shirts, locked up the three Filipino women beauticians in a room, threatening to kill them if they resisted, police said. Police said the suspects fled after ransacking the apartment. The women managed to free themselves and found Brown's bloody body in the dining room, police said. It was not known how much money or property was stolen. Suspected Communist rebels killed Marine Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette on May 4 in Olongapo, 50 miles west of Manila. On May 13, two U.S. airmen were slain near Clark. The Marxist New People's Army claimed responsibility for killing the airmen but has issued no statement on the Fredette slaying. In Angeles, 50 miles north of Manila, 500 troops and police backed by armored personnel carriers motored through the streets brandishing M-16 rifles and carrying banners denouncing the Communist rebels. The motorcade passed before Clark. Philippine police Lt. Col. Julius Yarcia announced the formation of neighborhood vigilante groups to help fight the rebels. ``We just want to convince the people that we are willing to fight and that we have the manpower and the firepower to fight the enemy,'' Yarcia said. The New People's Army, the military wing of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines, has waged a 21-year-old insurgency to establish a Marxist state. On Friday, U.S. officials announced renewed restrictions on the 20,300 troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents at Clark, largest of the six U.S. bases in the Philippines. Air Force spokesman Lt. Col. Ron Rand said military personnel living there were restricted to base and that those living off-post were told to confine travel to ``essential'' business. In a statement broadcast Saturday by the U.S. military's Far East Network, Rand said there had been no incidents involving Americans but the restrictions were ordered because of ``current threat conditions.'' He said security patrols around the sprawling base have been doubled to protect American lives. Because of the restrictions at Clark, the number of personnel taking part in Cope Thunder, a two-week Air Force training exercise scheduled to begin Monday, has been cut by 10 to 20 percent, said an Air Force spokesman in Hawaii. ``I want to make it clear that we are not scaling back the exercise because of any terroristic activities,'' said Maj. James Pasierb, public affairs officer at Pacific Air Forces headquarters at Hickam Air Force Base. Philippine intelligence sources said on condition of anonymity that rebel troop movements Friday prompted the restrictions on Clark personnel. Angeles has been a Communist stronghold since the 1940s. Yarcia said that in addition to the civilian vigilantes, two companies of troops from the elite Philippine Constabulary Regional Special Action Force would be sent to Angeles to augment the three battalions stationed in the city. U.S. officials had imposed restrictions after rebels killed U.S. Airmen John Raven and James Green, but relaxed them 12 days later on May 25. The two were slain outside a hotel in Angeles a day before U.S. and Philippine officials began talks on a new lease for the U.S. bases. Communist rebels oppose an extension of the lease, which expires next year. More talks between Philippine and U.S. negotiators are expected by July. Eight Americans have been slain in politically motivated violence since April 1989. In Bacolod, 300 miles south of Manila, Brig. Gen. Raymundo Jarque said Saturday that rebels might target foreign government and private relief workers throughout the Philippines to discourage foreign assistance. Last Tuesday, suspected rebels abducted Fumio Mizuno, 36, training director of Japan's Organization for Industrial, Spiritual and Cultural Advancement, at a silkworm farm near Bacolod. ``The reason for the abduction of Mizuno was to stop foreign aid in the province,'' Jarque said. Military sources said they believed Mizuno was alive but they had received no message from his abductors.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Put on Show of Force in Beijing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS five grafs after 2nd graf, Despite heavy ..., to UPDATE with police dispersing crowd in English Square, U.S. and Italian embassies denying reports that dissident physicist to be allowed to travel to Italy. Pickup 3rd graf pvs: On Saturday ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Chinese Dissidents, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Truckloads of soldiers roared through Tiananmen Square on Sunday in a show of force to head off any demonstrations marking last year's June 3-4 army attack on student pro-democracy protesters. Despite heavy security at the square and elsewhere in Beijing, a man tried to unfurl a protest poster near Tiananmen but police immediately dragged him off, witnesses said. In a park in western Beijing, police broke up a crowd of about 40 Chinese at the English Corner, a place where people studying English gather each Sunday morning to practice. The police took five people away for questioning. Authorities ordered the corner closed down in October but English aficionados have continued to gather weekly with only token efforts by police to shoo them away. Meanwhile, the U.S. and Italian embassies Sunday denied Italian news reports that China's leading dissident, astrophysicist Fang Lizhi, and his wife, Li Shuxiasn would be allowed to leave their shelter in the U.S. Embassy and travel to Italy. ``Any rumor concerning Fang, there's nothing to them,'' said U.S. Embassy press officer Sheridan W. Bell. ``There's nothing going on.'' The couple sought refuge in the U.S. Embassy last June shortly after the military suppression of the pro-democracy movement, and are wanted by Chinese police on charges of counterrevolutionary activities. On Saturday, sources in Shanghai said Wang Ruowang, a leading 71-year-old writer who participated in last year's protests, was arrested in September. He has not been seen in public since last summer. In Beijing, one student was seen Saturday wearing a T-shirt emblazoned with the pro-democracy movement's V-for-victory symbol. But there were no other signs outwardly marking the anniversary that day. ``The Chinese are very practical. They're not going to do anything that clearly will fail,'' said a student at Beijing Normal University, which was one of the protest centers. Security guards patrolled Beijing campuses, and armed sentries were posted at a major intersection next to the main foreign residential compound in Beijing on Saturday. The government warned foreign radio stations against broadcasting a taped program made by exiled Chinese dissidents. The dissidents had planned to broadcast from a ship off China's coast, but they abandoned the project when Taiwan refused to allow the ship to load its transmitter and Japan wouldn't allow the boat into Japanese ports. The protester Sunday approached Canadian Broadcasting Corp. journalists as they stood beneath Tiananmen Gate just north of the square, where the protesters had their headquarters last year. The man wore ordinary workers' clothes and appeared to be in his 50s, the journalists said. He unrolled a yellow poster for the journalists to see. But they were able to read only the opening words: ``To all foreign journalists: we have invented a new philosophy ...'' when police grabbed him and the poster, the reporters said. ``Rise up!'' the man shouted to bystanders as police hauled him into one of their many posts on the edge of the vast square. Twelve trucks of soldiers, each holding about 40, drove through the square in the early morning in a show of force. More than 100 soldiers practiced drills with riot sticks, truncheons and shields in front of the history museum on one side of the square, where soldiers have been quartered since May 1989. The square, where last year's protesters had their headquarters, was was closed to the public, but dozens of official buses, vans and cars were parked on it. Security around the square was unusually tight, with dozens of police vehicles parked on the edges and paramilitary police patrolling in pairs. A shiny new water cannon was parked on one side. On Saturday, authorities turned the square into a carnival ground for selected grammar school children. Elsewhere in the city, convoys of police vehicles with lights flashing drove through the city early Sunday. Tiananmen still bears the scars of tank treads from the night of June 3-4, 1989, when soldiers retook it from protesters demanding democratic reform. Hundreds and possibly thousands of people were killed by soldiers as they marched into the city on their way to the square. Some underground activists said they wanted to make a commemorative gesture on the square Sunday or Monday, but that it would be too dangerous. On at least one Beijing campus, teachers were assigned to make bed checks in student dormitories. At Beijing University and other schools, official dance parties were scheduled through the weekend to distract students. On Sunday, authorities planned a ceremony in the square to commemorate the 1840 Opium War against Britain, which official histories describe as an example of foreign imperialist aggression against China. The war was triggered by British trade in opium bought in India and sold in China, where it became a major social problem. On Monday, 2,000 taxis were to gather in the square to practice safe driving. Police have reported stepped-up arrests of vagrants and common criminals in Beijing and Shanghai in the past week, apparently part of the effort to keep order during the weekend. The only three political activists who have continued to openly criticize the government dropped out of sight Thursday and were believed in police custody. They had planned to release an open letter to the government calling for the release of last year's protesters. Hundreds remain jailed. The sources in Shanghai said Wang _ a prominent writer who marched along with student protesters in that city last spring _ was taken into police custody Sept. 8 after having been held under house arrest for two months. Wang's family has not been allowed to communicate with him, and he has not been formally charged, the sources said on condition of anonymity. Police said he was being investigated for alleged acts of counterrevolutionary incitement.

DOC.HEAD: Blockades Continue in Independent Truckers Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with nine grafs to UPDATE with talks ending for night, scheduled to resume Sunday, some grocery shelves emptied, gasoline running out in Washington resort town. Pick up 22nd graf, `Point Roberts ...'
DOC.TEXT: Negotiations overseen by a government mediator failed Saturday to end a week-old strike by independent truckers in British Columbia who have blocked U.S. border points. Meanwhile, worried shoppers stockpiled food because they feared the strike, which began last Sunday, will soon leave supermarket shelves bare. Some grocery shelves were emptied by panic buying. Provincial Solicitor General Russ Fraser on Friday appointed Brian Williams to mediate the bitter rate dispute between the truckers and the hauling industry. Williams met for six hours Saturday with trucking companies, the Western Owner Operators Association representing the independents, and the Teamsters Union, which speaks for union drivers. The talks failed to produce an agreement, but were scheduled to resume Sunday, Williams said. Fraser vowed on Friday that the border blockades would come down, but they remained in place Saturday, snarling traffic. Customs officials at border points said police were monitoring the situation but not interfering with the blockade. The striking independent truckers have blockaded the U.S.-Canadian border in British Columbia with their rigs, persuading or forcing American truckers to turn their vehicles around or park them. ``This is a major inconvenience to the public,'' Fraser said. Buses and cars were getting through, and so were trucks carrying medical supplies and mail, but everything else was being turned back. Some store owners said worried customers bought more food than usual because of the strike. ``Some people are stockpiling,'' said Ken Fowler, the manager of Thrifty Foods Fairfield store in Victoria. ``Business is up 10 per cent.'' Some items, including bananas and other imported produce, disappeared fast, he said. ``The big crunch will hit us next week,'' Fowler said, adding that 90 per cent of deliveries weren't getting through to his store. He said his chain is looking for an alternative delivery system. Sixty Overwaitea and Save-On-Foods stores were running low on stock last week, but spokesman Peter Walton said other delivery arrangements were being made. Cargo is also piling up at Vancouver-area docks. ``The impact is just starting,'' said Wayne Stoilen, vice-president of Canadian Stevedoring Co. ``We believe it will build up quite fast.'' The 3,000 independent truckers in British Columbia are hired by trucking companies that also run their own vehicles with union drivers. The independents, who pay their own running costs and maintain their vehicles, are paid between $22 and $30 an hour. They say they'll stay parked until their demand for $34 an hour is met. The independents are responsible for moving 25 per cent of the truck freight in British Columbia, but have also won support from unionized drivers. Since last Sunday, they have blockaded all border crossings, the Trans-Canada Highway at Yale, near Hope, and Highway 97 near Penticton. In an unusual twist, residents of Point Roberts, Wash., might soon have to head to Canada to buy gasoline and milk. At least one gasoline station in Point Roberts closed Saturday because it was out of gasoline. Operators of several others said they were close to running out. Point Roberts is reachable by land only through British Columbia and all deliveries of goods must travel through the province to reach the small community. Service stations in Point Roberts said they were running out of gasoline Saturday, and only one store had any milk left. Normally, the town is a popular spot for British Columbia residents to buy cheap U.S. groceries and gas.

DOC.HEAD: Roh Leaves For Talks With Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo left for San Francisco Sunday, saying that his talks with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev would open a new era in relations between the two once hostile nations. Roh is scheduled to meet Gorbachev in San Francisco on Monday after the Soviet president ends his summit talks with President Bush. Roh plans to leave for Washington on Tuesday to talk with Bush. In San Francisco, Mayor Art Agnos declared Sunday ``Roh Tae-woo Day'' in honor of the South Korean president. Agnos planned to present Roh with the key to the city upon his arrival at San Francisco International Airport Sunday morning. The Roh-Gorbachev meeting would be the first formal talks between the countries' leaders since the Republic of Korea was formed 45 years ago. The Soviet Union is an ally of South Korea's arch foe, communist North Korea. ``Our summit meeting will be an unusual one since our two countries have no diplomatic relations,'' Roh said during a brief departure ceremony at Seoul Airport. ``Accordingly, this is expected to open a new era in our relations with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics,'' he said. During his talks with Gorbachev, Roh said he would focus on bilateral issues, emphasizing the normalization of relations and measures to promote peace and unification of the divided Korean peninsula. ``I intend to exchange with President Gorbachev extensive views on how to spread to Northeast Asia, especially to the Korean peninsula, the waves of openness and cooperation now sweeping the world,'' he said. North Korean officials have denounced the planned Roh-Gorbachev meeting. North Korean President Kim Il-sung has refused to recognize the Seoul government. South Korean officials said the unprecedented talks could lead to an early normalization of relations between Seoul and Moscow and accelerate trade and economic cooperation between the two countries. The Soviet Union, which supported North Korea in the 1950-53 Korean War, has greatly expanded economic and other unofficial contacts with South Korea in recent years, especially after the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul. Their bilateral trade increased 10 times from 1985 to total $600 million last year and is expected to top $1 billion this year. They exchanged trade offices and opened limited consular relations last year. Observers here believe that the Roh-Gorbachev talks reflect Seoul's wish for normalized relations with the Soviet Union and Moscow's desire to induce more South Korean investment to help ease its economic problems. The talks represent a success for South Korea's policy of seeking improved ties with Communist nations which can exert influence on North Korea and help reduce tension on the Korean peninsula. The Korean peninsula was divided into the Communist North and capitalist South in 1945. The two Koreas have held talks on and off since the early 1970's but little progress has been made. Since 1988, South Korea has opened relations with all Eastern European nations except East Germany and Albania. South Korean officials said they are negotiating to establish ties with East Germany. Seoul officials believe that improved ties with the Soviet Union would also stimulate China, a close ally of North Korea, to establish diplomatic relations with South Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Tornadoes Rip Through Midwest, Leaving Dead, Injured in Path
LaserPhoto LFY1
DOC.TEXT: A state of emergency was declared in Indiana in the trail of twisters that killed at least nine people, injured more than 100 and littered the Midwest with debris, authorities said. At least 130 people were injured Saturday night in Indiana in about four tornadoes that touched down 50 times or more in the state. Eight people were reported killed in Indiana and one person was left dead in Illinois, officials said. A few of the injuries in Indiana were critical, state officials said. Elsewhere, twisters or tornado-force winds downed trees, knocked out power and damaged homes and businesses in Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Minnesota, Ohio and Wisconsin. Indiana Gov. Evan Bayh sent the state's National Guard to Bedford and Petersburg, the two hardest hit areas in southern Indiana. The Indiana National Guard dispatched medical workers, engineers and ambulances to the region, where state police set up a temporary command post to assist injured and homeless residents. A temporary morgue was set up at a fire station in Petersburg, a city of 4,000 people about 40 miles north of Evansville. ``It's like a war zone,'' said Ed Thurman of nearby Vincennes, who walked through Petersburg early today to view damage. ``Half of the town was destroyed,'' Thurman said. ``Homes, businesses, an elementary school. It went right down the main street. The mayor's house was demolished.'' Temporary shelters in churches quickly filled up in Petersburg, where flooding two weeks ago chased people from their homes, Thurman said. Randy Harris of radio station WFPC in Petersburg said he was home when disaster struck. ``It was just a very strong roar, almost like a low-flying jet,'' he said. Phil Roberts, deputy director of the Indiana Department of Emergency Management, said eight people were confirmed killed in Indiana _ four in Petersburg, two in nearby Union, one in Bedford, which is 70 miles south of Indianapolis, and one in Putnam County. Jerry Hauer, director of the state emergency management agency, initially had reported three people were killed in Bedford, but Roberts said early today that figure was based on reports from local authorities who later changed their count. One woman was killed in Putnam County when her mobile home overturned, said Hendricks County sheriff's Lt. Steve Golden. Details on the other deaths in Indiana remained sketchy early today. The tornadoes were deemed the most destructive to hit Indiana since 1974, when about a dozen twisters touched down, Hauer said. A woman in the small, southeastern Illinois town of Browns was killed and at least eight people in nearby Findlay and Newton were injured by tornadoes, officials said. Electricity and gas service was turned off in Findlay, where about 800 people live, for fear of leaks. Eleven homes were destroyed and 25 others were damaged in the area. Hospitals around the Bedford and Petersburg areas treated many of the Indiana injured, Roberts said. Utility service was knocked out in those areas. Mike Garvey, a medical specialist for the Indiana emergency management agency, said at least 75 people were injured in the Bedford and Petersburg areas. Fewer than ten were critically injured, he said. Among the injured were 27 people in a Bedford restaurant that was destroyed, Roberts said. A service station and convenience store were destroyed south of Bedford, witnesses said. Indiana State Police in Lafayette reported extensive damage in Montgomery County about 25 miles northwest of Indianapolis. At least two tornadoes touched down in that region. ``Some houses are reported gone,'' state police Cpl. Dave Murray said of Montgomery County. Elsewhere: _In Wisconsin, several thousand residents of Fond du Lac, an eastern Wisconsin city of 36,000, were temporarily without electric service as tree limbs tore down transmission lines. No serious injuries were reported. _In Minnesota, thunderstorms with wind gusts up to 70 mph and hail moved across southeastern and east-central parts of the state. A tornado damaged four farms Saturday one mile east of Goodhue in southeastern Minnesota, but no injuries were reported, authorities said. _ In Ohio, a tornado damaged several homes and destroyed a restaurant in Harrison, outside Cincinnati, the National Weather Service said. No serious injuries were reported. _ In Kentucky, a tornado overturned a house trailer and damaged three others in the town of West Liberty, and two possible tornadoes were reported elsewhere in the state, said police and the weather service. No injuries were immediately reported. _ In Michigan, a tornado touched down in Big Praire Township, damaging some of the many vacation trailers in an area where many retirees live, said Newago County sheriff's dispatcher Bob Bain. No injuries were reported and the extent of the damage was not immediately known, he said. _ In Kansas, winds that reached 70 mph tore roofs from homes throughout the city of Hutchinson. Downed power lines knocked out power to nearly 50,000 homes and sparked grass fires.

DOC.HEAD: Bush and Gorbachev Close To Wrapping Up Summit Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new graf after pvs 7th graf bgng, Before the, with Bush comment on Camp David talks.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev wrap up their four-day summit on Sunday still divided over the future of Germany and Lithuania, but saying their warm relationship will help them deal with the world's problems. ``There is ample opportunity for cooperation, even though there are real problems that neither the president nor I can turn a blind eye to,'' Gorbachev said Saturday after a day of relaxed conversation at Camp David. ``I set high store by the personal relationship that the president and I have established _ the personal rapport between us,'' he said. Bush, standing at Gorbachev's side before the two boarded a helicopter for the short ride back to Washington, said his view of the talks and his guest's were ``in close parallel.'' ``Some will argue that we haven't solved all the problems,'' he said. ``To me, that's not the point. The point is, we have an awful lot of common ground.'' Gorbachev said he and Bush had discussed the contentious issue of German unification and would talk more about it at their joint news conference Sunday prior to his departure for Minneapolis and San Francisco. Before the televised news conference in the White House East Room, Bush and his wife, Barbara, attended an early-morning communion service at St. John's Episcopal Church across Lafayette Square from the White House. Bush worships regularly at St. John's, the historic ``Church of the Presidents,'' when he is not spending weekends at Camp David. As he returned to the White House, Bush was asked if things had gone well in his Camp David discussions with Gorbachev. ``It was a good day, yeah,'' the president replied. The Soviet leader, concerned about the military strength of a united Germany, has opposed Bush's demand that the new nation be a full member of NATO. The issue was discussed extensively on the first summit day Thursday, but was set aside so the leaders could focus on other matters. There were hints of a Bush visit to Moscow as part of an agreement for regular meetings. ``There has been some discussion of visits back and forth,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. ``I think perhaps they'll have something to say at their press conference.'' Taking a break around lunchtime, Gorbachev and his wife took advantage of the brilliant weather to stroll around the mountaintop compound and stopped to pitch horseshoes _ one of Bush's favorite pastimes. Bush complained jokingly that although Gorbachev had never thrown horseshoes before, he managed to score a ``ringer'' by hooking one on a metal stake on his first try. ``Well, I couldn't give in after all,'' Gorbachev replied. At dinner, Bush said, Gorbachev explained ``that a horseshoe in the Soviet Union, when posted in one's house, symbolizes warmth and friendship. That made an impression on me.'' Saturday's agenda focused mostly on regional issues, including Nicaragua, Afghanistan, Cambodia, Cuba, El Salvador, India, Pakistan and the Middle East, spokesmen said. As Bush and Gorbachev ended their talks, the two sides issued a statement promising to work together to fight starvation in Ethiopia. They agreed to send food from the United States and have it delivered to Ethiopia on Soviet aircraft. Although the leaders did not dwell on the question of Soviet pressure on Lithuania, Fitzwater linked Moscow's conduct with the granting of U.S. trade benefits for the Soviet Union. He said ``it will be difficult'' to win Senate approval of a trade agreement announced by the leaders Friday _ along with two agreements on slashing long-range nuclear weapons and stocks of deadly gas canisters _ ``because the United States feels very strongly about Lithuania.'' In addition, Fitzwater said, ``This agreement is not going to the Congress until an emigration law is passed'' in the Soviet Union protecting free emigration.

DOC.HEAD: British Bus Crashes, At Least 11 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with police correcting the death toll to 11, sted 12. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Rescue workers...'
DOC.TEXT: A British tour bus burst a tire, swerved into a roadside ditch and overturned Sunday morning, killing at least 11 people and leaving another 61 injured, police reported. An earlier, erroneous police report said 12 died, but the region's under-prefect, Jean-Yves Caullet, said ``one body was counted twice.'' At least 22 of the injured people were reported in serious condition. They were taken to hospitals near the crash site, 100 miles south of Paris. Rescue workers used five cranes to gently lift the crushed double-decker bus to extract survivors, police said. All the survivors were pulled out of the wreckage by noon, almost four hours after the accident, according to police. The bus was traveling north at high speed about 8 a.m. near the village of Courtenay when a tire burst and the driver lost control, police said. The bus veered into a roadside ditch, flipped over on its side and was crushed by the impact, police said. No other vehicles were involved in the accident and the bus did not catch fire. The British Foreign Office said the bus came from Leek, in Staffordshire, central England. Police said most of the passengers were British. British diplomats from Paris and the French Secretary of State for Transport, Georges Sarre, traveled to the scene. The British Broadcasting Corp. reported that the bus was traveling on the main north-south highway toward the English Channel, taking holidaymakers home from the southern city of Nimes, where a series of bullfights and religious festivities related to the Pentecost were held this weekend.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Warns Israel on West Bank Settlements
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines a0712,a0713,a0715; CORRECTS `last year' to `last month' in 4th graf, bgng: Jewish emigration
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned Israel on Sunday he would consider suspending the issuance of exit permits for Soviet Jews if they continue to be settled on the West Bank or in Gaza. President Bush joined Gorbachev at a news conference winding up their four-day summit with a reiteration of U.S. opposition to further settlements on the lands captured from the Arabs in the 1967 Mideast War. ``I will try to persuade the government of Israel that it is counterproductive,'' Bush said. Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union is at an all-time high. Some 20,000 exit permits were issued last month. About 70,000 Soviet Jews are expected to enter the United States this year. Most of the others elect to go to Israel, where according to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir only about 1 percent settle on the West Bank and in Gaza. If East Jerusalem is included as occupied territory _ as Bush insists it should be _ the percentage rises to about 10 percent. Gorbachev, responding to a question, said the Soviet Union ``is being bombarded by a lot of criticism`` from Arab countries. He said Presidents Hafez Assad of Syria and Hosni Mubarak of Egypt had raised their objections ``in acute terms.'' He said if Israel did not heed appeals to keep Jews from the territories, ``we must give further thought to it in terms of what we can do with issuing permits for exit ... postpone issuing permits for exit.'' The Soviet leader did not make clear if the objections registered with him by Arab governments applied only to Jews going to the West Bank and Gaza or to their emigration to any part of Israel. The influx of Soviet Jews has been an unexpected boon to the Jewish state as it seeks to maintain a sizable population in a largely hostile Arab world. On a related front, Bush defended the U.S. decision to block a drive in the United Nations for sending permanent observers to the area to monitor the situation under the supervision of the U.N. Security Council. He said the U.S. preference was an inspection visit by a deputy of Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Bush sharply condemned last week's guerrilla attack on Israel. ``It is unacceptable,'' he said. Turning to the settlements issue, though, he said: ``U.S. policy is unchanged and clear. We oppose new settlements in territories beyond the 1967 lines.'' Some 70,000 Jews have settled on the West Bank and in Gaza since the territories were surrendered by Jordan and Egypt. U.S. policy seeks a withdrawal by Israel, without specifying if all the land should be relinquished in exchange for recognition by the Arabs. Egypt in 1979 signed a peace treaty with Israel and reacquired all the land in Sinai it had lost in the 1967 war.

DOC.HEAD: Police Conscript Dies Following Beating; Six Officers Suspended
DOC.TEXT: A young man drafted into the police force was beaten to death and authorities suspended six officers pending an investigation, police sources said Sunday. Attorney General Abdel-Aziz Mokhtar will lead the investigation into the death of 22-year-old Sultan Abdel-Hamid in Assiut, 230 miles south of the capital, Cairo, the sources said. Abdel-Hamid was severely beaten on his arms and legs and died in a hospital, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymnity. They did not specify when the incident took place or when the three police officers and three sergeants were suspended. All men between 18 and 35 are required to serve in the Central Security police. University graduates spend one year while non-university graduates spend up to three years. The conscripts are usually based in ill-equipped camps in the desert and sometimes badly treated. In 1986, thousands rampaged near the Giza pyramids, burning hotels and cars in protest of a rumor that the government had extended their conscription periods.

DOC.HEAD: Italians Vote on Limiting Hunting, Use of Pesticides
DOC.TEXT: Italians began voting Sunday in a two-day referendum on restricting hunting and the use of pesticides. If approved, the measures would cancel laws or regulations on hunting and pesticides, forcing Parliament to enact stricter legislation. About 46.8 million people were eligible to vote in the election, which was scheduled to end Monday afternoon. More than half the eligible voters must cast ballots for the referendum to be considered valid.

DOC.HEAD: Jail Crowding Worsens as New Inmates Outstrip Construction
DOC.TEXT: Overcrowding in the nation's jails worsened between 1988 and 1989 as construction of new cells failed to keep pace with a 15 percent jump in the number of prisoners, the Justice Department said Sunday. The capacity of local jails expanded 8 percent between the middle of 1988 and midyear 1989, according to the study by the department's Bureau of Justice Statistics. On June 30, 1989, there were 395,553 prisoners held in jails operated by local governments designed to hold 367,769 people, the study said. That marked a 15 percent increase from the 343,569 prisoners in custody on the same day in 1988, when the jails had a rated capacity of 339,633. The average daily population of the nation's local jails for the 12 months ending June 30, 1989, was 386,845, also up 15 percent from an average of 336,017 for the same 12-month period ending June 30, 1988, the study said. The occupancy rate of the nation's jails increased from 101 percent to 108 percent between the two periods, the study said. In 1983, the occupancy rate of nation's jails was 85 percent and in 1976 it was 65 percent. Overcrowding was worse in the jurisdictions that had the largest number of inmates. The occupancy rate averaged 116 percent in the 508 local jurisdictions that held at least 100 inmates. These jurisdictions had 81 percent of the nation's jail prisoners. State prison overcrowding also contributed to the problem in local jails, according to the study. The study found that 88 percent of the 508 largest jurisdictions held 42,053 prisoners for other authorities, including 29,358 inmates that had been sent to local jails because of overcrowding elsewhere, the study said. Twenty-six percent of these jurisdictions were under a court order to reduce overcrowding at one or more jails and 23 percent had been ordered by judges to improve conditions. Despite the increased overcrowding, the number of inmate deaths declined from 469 during 1988 to 414 last year, the study said. The number of jail suicides declined from 147 to 121. There were 19 million admissions and releases from local jails during the 12-month period ending June 30, 1989. The average daily population of female jail inmates jumped 27 percent between 1988 and 1989. Women comprised 9 percent of all jail inmates in 1989, the study said. The study surveyed local jails that hold inmates after arraignment, usually more than 48 hours. Police lockups that house prisoners, usually drunks, for less than 48 hours were not included. State-run jails and the combined jail-prison systems of Alaska, Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Rhode Island and Vermont were not included in the survey.

DOC.HEAD: Underground Spring Floods Mine, At Least 24 Workers Dead
DOC.TEXT: Miners broke open an underground spring and it flooded their zinc and lead mine, killing at least 24 workers 1,000 feet below the surface, authorities reported Sunday. The accident occurred Saturday night at the Ain Azel mine in eastern Algeria, the government-owned National Enterprise for Non-Ferrous Products reported. At least 24 miners and possibly more died when the waters rushed through the underground caverns. Three people were quickly rescued, but authorities said they held little hope of finding other survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Desmond Harmsworth, Newspaperman Who Turned To Art, Dead
DOC.TEXT: Desmond Harmsworth, who was born into one of Britain's great newspaper dynasties but quit his publishing job to become an artist, has died at age 86, his family said Sunday. Harmsworth died Saturday at his home in Egham, near London. The cause of death was not disclosed. Harmsworth was of the Harmsworth and Northcliffe families, which control Associated Newspapers, publishers of London's Daily Mail and other daily and weekly papers. He worked as a journalist and publisher for the families' newspapers before turning to painting in the early 1930s. He moved to Paris, where Irish author James Joyce was among those who posed for him. His paintings were exhibited in London, New York, Paris, Washington and Dallas. As a publisher, Harmsworth had been among the first to print Joyce's poetry and the works of the U.S. poet Ezra Pound. He also wrote poetry and translated the French poet Paul Valery. When World War II began, Harmsworth was painting in Tahiti but moved to New York, where he worked in the British Information Services. In 1926, he married Dorothy Heinlein of Bridgeport, Ohio, who survives him with their only child, Margaret, who is also an artist. Harmsworth became the 2nd Baron Harmsworth after his father's death in 1948. The title passes to his nephew, Thomas Harmsworth.

DOC.HEAD: Fragmented Underground Continues Call for Democracy
DOC.TEXT: An hour before dawn, a college dropout pastes notices onto alley walls and slips them through mail slots. ``Citizens who want China to be strong and prosperous, destroy this national impasse and struggle for China's future,'' they say. A red stamp proclaims the notices to be from the Committee of the Mainland Alliance for Democracy, ``Lie Ma, director.'' Lie Ma is the collective pseudonym of the group's six members. ``Chinese people are gossips,'' said the college dropout, one of the six. ``Leave one notice and pretty soon the whole neighborhood knows. If it's an old woman who finds it, even better. You can always rely on her to talk.'' He said the goal is simple: ``We want to create an unstable situation in Beijing.'' One year after the army crushed the largest demonstrations under Communist rule, muffled but persistent voices of discontent continue to rise from underground, defying stringent security measures. The Mainland Alliance is one of several tiny groups formed to continue the democracy movement that was silenced above ground when soldiers fired on demonstrators in Beijing last June 3-4. Some groups are known only from crudely mimeographed political manifestos distributed hand to hand, or from typed leaflets left in public places. One leaflet is signed simply, ``A group of Beijing citizens and students.'' Other underground activists have approached foreign journalists in Beijing, hoping to spread their message and discomfit the nation's aging leaders. A group in western China calls itself the Chinese Democratic Front, apparently in imitation of the Chinese exile group based in Paris, which the Chinese government made famous by criticizing it. The domestic Front says it has no contact with the Paris group. The Democratic Front for the Salvation of China, led by one of last year's student protest leaders, Zhai Weimin, announced its formation in March. Zhai's group is unusual because he remains in hiding, fugitive No. 6 on a government list of the 21 most-wanted student leaders. Most other underground activists lead normal, open lives _ as students, workers, professors and even police officials. The picture that emerges from talks with underground activists and other Chinese sources is of separate groups, each with six to 12 members, in at least half a dozen major cities. These are not the first underground political groups to exist since the Communist Party gained power in 1949, but taken collectively, they may be the largest such movement. There is no nationwide network. Some groups are aware of the activities of others or have occasional contacts, but they prefer to operate in isolation and rely only on trusted friends. They are tightly knit, inexperienced and fearful, but they are learning, the college dropout said. When he arrived for an interview, two friends were posted nearby to watch for plainclothes police. He said the group's equipment includes invisible ink and a few mimeograph machines smuggled out of last spring's protest headquarters on Tiananmen Square. A public security official is the committee's mainstay, but not a member. He has taught the six how to recognize plainclothes officers and police vehicles, how to evade tails and what to do if questioned by security officials. ``We are not against the government or the party,'' the dropout said. ``We think the Communist Party can reform. We want to force it to reform.'' He said the first objective is to force the party to reverse its verdict that last year's protests were counterrevolutionary, which would free the participants from lifelong political taint. The Democratic Front for the Salvation of China and the Chinese Democratic Front want a multiparty system. The latter's political platform calls for a ``genuinely democratic political system that guarantees the whole people hold the highest political power,'' including general elections and a free press. A statement from the Chinese Democratic Front, also made up of about six people, said: ``Our country has a tradition of fighting a feudal political system, but the people also have a tradition of fighting feudal autocratic control. ``Our dream of democracy, freedom, equality, justice and dignity is as strong as that of other races. ... We do not love enslavement. We have suffered enough.''

DOC.HEAD: Activists Prepare For `Redwood Summer' Protests Against Logging
DOC.TEXT: Leftist activists of all stripes, spurred by a bombing that injured two environmentalists, are preparing for a widespread anti-logging protest campaign they're calling Redwood Summer. Earth First! organizers said they hope to reproduce the environmental equivalent of Freedom Summer, the 1964 voter registration campaign centered in Mississippi that helped lead to the 1965 Voting Rights Act. Though Redwood Summer protests are planned as peaceful civil disobedience to slow the pace of logging and save old-growth redwoods, a number of violent incidents already have occurred because of tension between those who make their living from the northern California timber industry and environmentalists. A letter writer, identified only as ``the Lord's avenger,'' has claimed responsibility for a pipe bomb explosion that injured Earth First! leaders Judi Bari and Darryl Cherney in Oakland on May 24. The writer also claimed responsibility for a pipe bomb that exploded outside a lumber mill May 9. Earlier, Bari and Cherney reported receiving numerous death threats, and last August her car was allegedly rammed by a logging truck. During demonstrations, a protester had her nose broken by a logger and another protester was dropped by a punch from another logger. To that extent, Redwood Summer resembles Freedom Summer, which was marked by violence, including the murder of three civil rights workers near Philadelphia, Miss. Police arrested Bari and Cherney, saying they knowingly carried the bomb when it blew up inside their car. But so far no charges have been filed against them. Earth First! founder Dave Foreman said in interviews that he believes the car bombing was an attempt to derail Redwood Summer. ``Dari and Cherney were giving it all they had. Why would they risk losing it all?'' he said. Redwood Summer is the kind of event ``that could galvanize national and even international opinion to stop the destruction of old-growth temperate rain forests,'' Foreman said. ``Just like Mississippi Summer that finally turned public opinion around and brought about the passage of the Civil Rights Act.'' Foreman is under federal indictment on charges of plotting last year to destroy transmission lines serving nuclear plants in California, Colorado and Arizona. The car bombing already has helped pull activists involved in other issues to the anti-logging campaign. Amnesty International, which investigates allegations of politically motivated violence against individuals worldwide, has offered to look into the bombing incident. ``We've had a multitude of groups step forward,'' Pam Davis, an Earth First! organizer, told a cheering audience last month at an anti-logging rally in Santa Rosa. Daniel Barron, an Earth First! member in San Francisco, said that the group is starting to form alliances with organizations in the peace, labor and environmental movements that might have been enemies or ``lukewarm to us in the past.'' Offers include manpower, money, technical support and non-violence training, organizers said. They said the recruits include Greenpeace; the Christic Institute, which claims a secret government undertakes illegal operations such as the Iran-Contra affair; Industrial Workers of the World; Rainforest Action Network; Pledge of Resistance, which opposes U.S. policy in Central America; and United Student Action, which calls itself the nation's largest progressive student group. Many of the activists span the political spectrum but say they have a common foe: capitalist power and its abuses. They are involved in a wide array of issues, including support of organized labor, the right to abortion, increased AIDS funds and equal rights for women and minorities. As for logging, environmentalists say they are frustrated by official failure to restrain timber companies from cutting down more trees than they've been growing. Timber officials deny that, and government representatives say the industry has been properly regulated. Redwood Summer's kickoff protest is scheduled at the Port of Sacramento on Thursday, with a demonstration at a log exporting business.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Does Not Keep Bushes From Attending Church
DOC.TEXT: President Bush did not let the summit interfere with church Sunday. The president and his wife, Barbara, attended a 25-minute communion service at St. John's Episcopal Church, just across Lafayette Square from the White House. The Bushes usually worship at the historic ``Church of the Presidents'' on the infrequent weekends they do not stay at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md. The Bushes and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, spent Saturday in the relaxed confines of the mountaintop compound at Camp David, but returned to the capital Saturday night. Bush was asked as he returned from church if things had gone well at Camp David. ``It was a good day, yeah,'' the president replied as he headed inside the White House to greet the Gorbachevs one last time for coffee and the summit finale news conference in the East Room. There were only 45 people at the 8 a.m. church service, where the altar was draped in bright red for Pentecost. The Rev. Anne Gavin Amy read a gospel about the Holy Spirit descending in tongues of fire upon the apostles after Christ's ascension to heaven. The Bushes both took communion. The Rev. John C. Harper, the rector, escorted Bush out a side entrance to his car, telling the president, ``I'm going to pray for you.'' Harper is scheduled to deliver the invocation at the President's Dinner, a annual Republican fund-raiser being held this year on June 12, which is Bush's 66th birthday.

DOC.HEAD: Roh And Gorbachev To Discuss Easing Tension On Korean Peninsula
LaserPhoto SEL2
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo meets Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev Monday for historic talks on normalizing relations and easing hostilities on the divided Korean peninsula, the last outpost of the Cold War. Roh traveled to San Fransisco Sunday for the meeting, the first between leaders of the two countries, which for most of the past four decades have viewed one another with hostility. The talks are the culmination of Seoul's efforts to court reformist Warsaw Pact countries to broaden trade ties and influence Soviet-backed North Korea, which is headed by Kim Il Sung, the longest-ruling Communist dictator. From all indications, the meeting was arranged hastily with the blessing of the United States. There was no firm agenda. Gorbachev was to be in San Francisco sightseeing following his summit with President Bush. Roh planned to fly to Washington to see Bush Wednesday before returning to Seoul. ``The waves of reform now reshaping the world have started rushing toward Northeast Asia,'' Roh said as he departed. He said he hoped talks with Gorbachev would forge a new era in efforts ``to pave the way for the peace and unification of the Korean peninsula.'' ``Korea now remains the only country on earth that is still divided as a legacy of the Cold War,'' Roh said. He is expected to invite Gorbachev to visit Seoul and may seek Moscow's help in arranging a summit meeting with Kim. Roh will press for early and full diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union and ask for protection of Seoul's growing trade and economic exchanges with Moscow. The South Korean president also is expected to propose a conference on easing tensions, bringing together the Koreas and the four powers with interests in Northeast Asia _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Japan and China, news reports said. Seoul and Moscow both have an economic stake in increasing trade and in helping defuse tensions on the peninsula, divided into the capitalist South and the Communist North since 1945. The two Koreas fought a three-year war in the early 1950s. A peace treaty was never signed and the border between the nations is the most heavily fortified boundary in the world today. The North has an estimated 1.1 million armed troops and South Korea has 650,000. Last week, the North renewed its 1988 proposal calling for both Koreas to reduce forces to 100,000 armed men in three to four years. The United States, which has 43,000 troops stationed in South Korea, has declared strong support for improvement in South-North relations and is trying to improve its own relations with the North's government in Pyongyang. North Korea has denounced the Roh-Gorbachev meeting and said that if it occurs, ``it will be a serious political issue.'' The criticism from North Korea could have prompted Moscow to treat the encounter casually, as a meeting of leaders whose paths happen to cross in California. The day before the meeting, Moscow still had not announced it. For its part, Moscow may voice support of North Korea's call for the signing of a peace treaty, withdrawal of all nuclear weapons and the pullout of all U.S. troops in South Korea. South Korean news reports say Moscow has requested from $3 billion to $5 billion worth of loans and aid before increasing its trade and consular ties to full diplomatic relations. The Seoul government has not denied that aid is a possibility. Trade between the two countries was $600 million last year and is expected to top $1 billion in 1990. South Korean media have given enthusiastic coverage to the Roh-Gorbachev meeting. There are stories on everything from Soviet trade, food and handicrafts to new demand for Russian language lessons. Seoul has established diplomatic relations with every East European country except Albania and East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Plays to Home Audience While Also Wooing Americans
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Intense Soviet television coverage of the Washington summit put Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the tricky position of addressing two audiences at the same time -- and trying to make sure each got the right message. For four days, Gorbachev sought to persuade American political leaders, Hollywood celebrities, intellectuals, ordinary people _ and, of course, President Bush _ that he has world as well as Soviet security at heart in bargaining on arms cuts, that he's being reasonable about Lithuania and that the Soviet Union has legitimate reasons to have something to say about the military future of Germany. At the same time, he was sending messages home to let his constituents know he was pushing hard for a trade deal to help the struggling Soviet economy while hanging tough on Lithuania and Germany. In the final minutes of his Washington visit, he was asked by a Soviet reporter _ at a news conference televised live to the Soviet Union as well as the United States _ to comment on his political rivalry back home with Boris Yeltsin. ``I don't think you have chosen the best place for clarifying our internal problems, but c'est la vie, as they say,'' Gorbachev smilingly replied, as the White House audience laughed. He then used the opportunity to take a few political potshots, saying Yeltsin had recently changed his position on important issues and scolding him with the comment that ``this is not a political game.'' ``Everything will become clear pretty soon what Comrade Yeltsin is after,'' Gorbachev told his two-nation audience. From the moment he arrived last Wednesday, Gorbachev showed his sensitivity to press coverage by calling Soviet diplomats and journalists to the Soviet Embassy to ask how the American press was reporting Soviet affairs. The answer was mixed. ``We said the American press generally was showing good will, but of course, there were various points of view,'' said Albert I. Vlasov, chairman of the Novosti Press Agency. Practically all his public appearances were beamed back to the Soviet Union, where his popularity has been falling as economic conditions deteriorate and where his critics were seeking to take advantage of his absence. The dual message was most apparent at a breakfast meeting Friday with congressional leaders. He talked at length about rising bread prices and other domestic economic problems _ a lecture shown in prime time on Soviet television. While ostensibly talking to American politicians, Gorbachev was actually seeking to reassure Soviet workers. More specifically, he was defending himself against a rear guard attack by Yeltsin, the populist reformer who last week was elected president of the Russian republic, the heart of the Soviet Union. In Gorbachev's absence, Yeltsin opened talks with Lithuanian independence leaders and called for the resignation of Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who last month introduced an unpopular plan to raise Soviet food prices. Gorbachev said in his breakfast talk that the salary of ordinary workers would be cushioned against the price rises. He also reiterated his position that Lithuania was ``breaking the rules of the game'' by declaring immediate independence instead of following the Soviet law on secession _ a point he reiterated vigorously at the Sunday news conference. On the Lithuanian issue, Gorbachev walked a public relations tightrope during the summit, trying to make his position appear conciliatory to Americans while sending tough signals home. He was aided by Soviet ``spin doctors'' _ official commentators who sought to discredit the Lithuanians in the eyes of the American press. One of these, Yuri V. Golik, chairman of the Supreme Soviet Committee on Law Enforcement, went so far as to tell reporters that Lithuania has a high crime rate ``as a natural consequence of the political turbulence and adventurism under way there.'' Gorbachev also sent subtly conflicting messages to his two audiences on the question of Germany's unification and possible membership in NATO. On one hand, he seemed to want to reach accommodation with the West, offering ``new ideas'' and assigning Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to work on specifics with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. On the other hand, he did not publicly back away from the Soviets' hard line against NATO membership for a united Germany. And he made pointed references in his arrival statement at the White House and in the final news conference to the Soviet Union's heavy losses against Nazi Germany in World War II. ``For Gorbachev, the German question is the toughest of all international issues in terms of public opinion at home,'' said Fyodor Burlatsky, a former speechwriter for then-Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev and a prominent Soviet commentator on international affairs. Even if the Soviet Union is unable to prevent German membership in NATO, he added, ``Gorbachev must show our people that he is doing everything he can to prevent Germany from becoming a future threat.''

DOC.HEAD: No More Obstacles for Murder Trial of Diplomat's Son Who Fought Extradition
DOC.TEXT: After years of international legal wrangling, the U.S. murder trial of a West German diplomat's son accused of slashing his girlfriend's wealthy parents to death has no more obstacles. Jens Soering, 23, is accused of killing Derek and Nancy Haysom in March 1985 with help from their daughter because they opposed the romance. He goes on trial this week before the local ``yokels'' he once bragged would never bring him back. The Haysoms were stabbed repeatedly and both victims' throats were cut. Elizabeth Haysom, 26, is serving a 90-year prison term after admitting she helped plan the slayings. She did not fight extradition after the fugitive couple was arrested in London in 1986. Soering ultimately took his case against extradition to the European Court of Human Rights, which ruled last July that he should not be returned to the United States because he faced a possible death sentence. Virginia prosecutors won his extradition after promising British officials that capital murder charges would be reduced to first-degree murder carrying a maximum penalty of two life sentences. Soering arrived in January. Jury selection was completed Friday and trial was scheduled to begin this week. ``Time has caught up with all of us,'' Bedford County Circuit Judge William Sweeney said. Soering is the son of Klaus Soering, a diplomat previously serving as vice consul at the West German Consulate in Detroit. The elder Soering is now stationed in Mauritania, Africa, but was in court Friday. During the protracted extradition battle, Soering's attorneys sought to have him tried in his native country, where there is no death penalty and he would have faced a maximum 10- to 15-year prison term. In a letter to Ms. Haysom written about four months after their arrest, Soering scoffed at the early extradition efforts of Virginia authorities. ``Those yokels don't know what's coming down,'' he wrote in the letter made public during Ms. Haysom's legal proceedings. He predicted he would go to West Germany, ``and then I'll be out in a surprisingly short time.'' Soering and Ms. Haysom began their relationship while both were students at the University of Virginia. During school breaks, Ms. Haysom wrote to Soering, who was home in Detroit, about how she hated her parents and that they could be rich and happy together only if her parents were dead. In recorded statements to investigators played during a pretrial hearing, Soering said he went to the Haysoms' home the night they were killed to confront them about their opposition to his relationship with their daughter. On the tape, he said there was an argument and the Haysoms were dead when he left, but declined to answer when asked if he stabbed them. Investigators concluded Ms. Haysom was not in the house at the time. Haysom, 72, was a retired steel industry executive. He was stabbed 39 times. Mrs. Haysom, 53, was stabbed five times. Their daughter testified at her sentencing hearing that she hated and resented her parents, but was merely indulging in ``grotesque, childish fantasies'' when plotting their deaths. Author Ken Englade's recently released book ``Beyond Reason,'' chronicles the Haysoms' story and was read by some courtroom spectators during lulls in the pretrial hearings. Englade said a television movie based on his book is under consideration and he plans to add a final chapter after Soering's trial is completed. ``These are people of intelligence and education involved in a very serious crime for no apparent reason,'' Englade said in a recent interview from his New Mexico home. ``These kids had such a bright future.''

Here is a text of the joint news conference Sunday by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev: PRESIDENT BUSH: Hello, everybody. Please be seated. Well, when President Gorbachev and I were in Malta, we agreed that we would try to build a fundamentally different U.S.-Soviet relationship, one that would move beyond containment to an era of enduring cooperation. At the time, no one knew the momentous events would unfold around the world. And our task is, if anything, more urgent and the case for a new U.S.-Soviet relationship more compelling, because the opportunities before us are so great. We've not shied away from discussing issues about which we disagree. There were some tough ones before us _ particularly the aspiration of the Baltic peoples, a cause which the United States fully supports. I think it's a mark of how far the U.S.-Soviet relationship has come that in all our exchanges, whether about issues on which we agreed or disagreed, the spirit of candor and openness, a desire not just to understand but to build bridges, has shown through. President Gorbachev and I had intensive discussions on the transforming events in Europe _ events that have put before us our best chance in four decades to see Europe whole and free. I stressed that the long-held aspirations of the German people should be met without delay. On the matter of Germany's external alliances, I believe, as do Chancellor Kohl and the members of the alliance, that the united Germany should be a full member of NATO. President Gorbachev, frankly, does not hold that view. But we are in full agreement that the matter of alliance membership is, in accordance with the Helsinki Final Act, a matter for the Germans to decide. Over the last six months and in Washington this week, we made great progress in our mutual effort toward building a more peaceful and stable world. We signed a very important chemical weapons accord, nuclear testing protocols, and gave a political push to others, including negotiations to reduce U.S.-Soviet strategic nuclear forces and conventional military forces in Europe. I'm also hopeful that the good discussion between President Gorbachev and the one we had about the importance of open skies will revive those negotiations. We discussed regional issues and human rights in considerable detail, made progress in the economic sphere, concluding a commercial agreement, a long-term grains agreement. And in closing, let me say how productive I really feel the last few days have been. President Gorbachev and I have agreed to meet on a regular basis, perhaps annually. Both of us would like to think that we can get together more often with less formality. Because, you see, we're now at a stage in the U.S.-Soviet relationship and, indeed, in world history where we should miss no opportunity to complete the extraordinary tasks before us. Mr. President, it's been a pleasure having you here, sir. PRESIDENT GORBACHEV (through interpreter): Ladies and gentlemen, comrades, what has happened over these days enables me to characterize this summit meeting as an event of enormous importance, both for our bilateral relations and in the context of world politics. President Bush has listed the results of the work that we've done together here which enables you to see the scope _ the scale of this work _ and I think confirms the conclusion that I have drawn. I agree with President Bush fully, who many times emphasized that we took Malta as a point of departure and it is Malta that added momentum to the process which, of course, must _ given all the difficulties and disagreements which we have and which we do not deny _ still leads us to a qualitatively new relationship with the USSR and the USA. The atmosphere and the results of this meeting make it possible for us to speak really of a new phase of cooperation which the president has just mentioned. I believe that this transition is both the result and a factor for further changes that affect all countries. The constructive spirit of these days, the spirit of responsibility, in which we discussed all questions have made our success possible, and that's really important because that has a stabilizing effect on the entire international situation at a time when we are addressing fundamental issues of civilization. I would not want to now list _ give a listing of all that we discussed, to mention all the agreements, all the important questions and statements that we have made and that have a lot of potential for the future. But, let me still mention what is most important. We signed the main provision for a treaty on the reduction of strategic arms. And I would like to emphasize that this is the first time that we're not just limiting, but we will be reducing the most devastating means of warfare. And I hope that we will sign the treaty itself this year. We also signed a statement about the future treaty negotiations on nuclear and space arms. We have agreed to make sure that we will complete the Vienna talks this year and sign an agreement on conventional arms at a European summit by the end of this year. Not everything depends on us, but this is our position. We want to achieve that. We also discussed problems relating to the European process, specifically, external aspects of German unification. I cannot say that we have reached agreement, but that does not mean that our efforts were futile. Many new arguments emerged as a result of these discussions and new possible perspectives. We have clarified our positions and it is our position that we will continue discussion in order to find a mutually acceptable solution. We could not resolve this issue in Washington, with the president, the two of us. There is also the two-plus-four formula and other European countries which are concerned, and which want to see a mutually acceptable solution, a solution acceptable to all of us. The position of the Soviet Union is that we have to find solutions that would fit into the overall positive trend of changes in Europe and in the world, that would strengthen and not erode security. I would like, in particular, to emphasize the importance of our dialogue at Camp David, where we talked during the day yesterday, and this is a new phase in strengthening mutual understanding and trust between us.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: between us.
DOC.TEXT: We really discussed all world problems. We compared our political perspectives, and we did that in an atmosphere of frankness, constructive atmosphere, an atmosphere of growing trust. We discussed specifically such urgent international issues as the situation in the Middle East, Afghanistan, southern Africa, Cambodia, Central America. That is just some of what we have discussed. I would not want to go into detail right now. I think that you will probably seek to get clarification on this, but anyway I think that the Camp David dialogue was very important. We have agreed to make a special statement on Ethiopia to support efforts to re-establish peace there and also, with the help of the United Nations, to give humanitarian relief to the Ethiopian people. Speaking of bilateral relations, we have some important political achievements here. Specifically, there is movement on such important areas as trade agreement, grain trade, agreement on civil aviation cooperation, maritime agreement, peaceful uses of atomic energy, science and technology, and education. While we and the president were working and our ministers were also discussing things, there were important contact discussions with various American companies, and some important decisions were made, such as Chevron, that will be participating in the exploration of the Tengiz oil fields. That will mean an investment of about 10 billion rubles. A group of our academicians were here with me, and they had a good discussion which resulted in the signing of a memorandum of intent with IBM, which will participate in the program of using computers for education in the Soviet Union. I think that this economic area and other areas create a good foundation for our political dialogue and creates a kind of solid support _ solid pillar of support _ for our cooperation. I would like to express my profound gratification at this work that we have done together with President George Bush. I appreciate very much him as a political leader who is able, in a very human way, and in a politically responsible way, to engage in dialogue and cooperation. We spent many hours together and were able to come to know each other very well. I don't know whether anyone will be ever able to say that we know each other totally well or completely. I think that would take many, many years. But now we have a good human relationship and, I think, a good human atmosphere between us. The president has said, and I would like to confirm this, that we have decided to have regular meetings on a working basis in a businesslike manner, and this is really what is necessary. I would like to tell you that I've invited President George Bush, the president of the United States, to visit the Soviet Union, to come for a state visit to our country. In concluding, and that is something that is not within the framework of the official negotiations but was part of our visit, I would like to say both to the Americans and to the Soviet people that here we, the Soviet delegation, we have felt very good feelings of the American people, feelings of solidarity and a lot of interest from the Americans toward what we are doing in the Soviet Union for perestroika. I have felt that on many occasions in my short exchanges with the Americans and also in various talks. I would like to thank all Americans for that, and they certainly can expect reciprocity from the Soviet Union for that. And finally, we, the two of us, were discussing things of concern to us _ various regions, various problems affecting the lives of other countries. But that does not mean that we were trying to decide anything for others. Anyway, we remembered always that what we were doing must be useful not only for our countries but for the world and, of course, specifically for that Third World. And let me at this wrap up my initial remarks at this press conference. QUESTION: I'd like to ask both presidents about Germany. President Bush, you mentioned that you still have a disagreement about the united Germany being in NATO. In any concrete sense, did you narrow your differences on this subject? And are any alternatives being seriously considered? PRESIDENT BUSH: I'm not sure we narrowed them. I feel I understand President Gorbachev's position, but I know this for a fact certain _ I had every opportunity to explain in considerable detail why I felt a united Germany in NATO would be stabilizing, would be important for the stability of a post-German unification Europe. So, I can't say whether we narrowed them. But the benefit of a meeting like this is, once again, you can talk in great frankness about it. I have no suspicion about his position, and I hope he has no suspicion about mine. And we've got collective decisions to take with NATO allies on matters of this nature. And -- but in the final analysis, it's a question for Germany to decide that. And maybe we're closer on that, but I would defer to President Gorbachev. PRESIDENT GORBACHEV: Since I have already made quite a few remarks on many occasions during these days on this subject, I will confine myself to comments which I think important in order to emphasize the thinking on this score, and in order for us to understand better what they're after. We're not insisting that it should be an option of the Soviet Union. We are not saying that this should be a version by the United States of America or anybody else's option. What we are talking about is an option or a solution of external problems related to Germany unification, which would organically incorporate the European process and improvement of international politics as a whole. In order for, so that a solution of these issues would help enrich this process and make it more stable and reliable, we're opposed to any options whatever it may come from. We, ourselves, are not going to offer one, one that would weaken these processes or create difficulties for the unfolding processes in the European continent. We're not going to put spokes in the wheels, as it were. So I believe the fact that the president, myself and our colleagues have devoted a great deal of time to this issue, we have threshed out this idea very, very thoroughly. I think (it) has been very helpful and beneficial because we will continue our debates on this.
