DOC.TEXT: Students at Beijing University hurled bottles and bricks from dormitory balconies at security forces Sunday night and rallied on campus, shouting ``Get rid of (Premier) Li Peng!'' The protest came on the anniversary of last year's June 3-4 army attack on pro-democracy demonstrators, including students from Beijing University and other schools. Hundreds and possibly thousands of people were killed. The protest was the strongest such demonstration since the crackdown. To prevent commemorations, soldiers and police imposed the heaviest security Beijing has seen since martial law was lifted in January. Many students had said they were too afraid to commemorate the anniversary. That was not the case in Hong Kong, where tens of thousands of Chinese demonstrated. ``We won't forget June 4'' and ``We are not scared,'' banners read in Hong Kong, which reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. Police said 100,000 people joined the march; organizers said more than 200,000 rallied. Smaller demonstrations were held in Taiwan, Japan, Britain, Canada and the United States. In Beijing, convoys of police vehicles with flashing lights and soldiers on foot circled the university district all evening, while security forces checked vehicles at major intersections. Witnesses said the protest began when a small group of graduate students hurled bottles, rusty bicycle wheels and other objects at security forces on the street beneath their dormitory windows. The students then marched to other dormitories, gathering hundreds of supporters and singing the Internationale _ the theme song of the international socialist movement that was frequently sung by last year's student protesters. Several students made speeches calling for an end to corrupt government and respect for intellectuals. One student demanded that land be returned to the peasants and factories to the workers. Students shouted ``Get rid of (Premier) Li Peng!'' Of all the Chinese leadership involved in the crackdown, Li is the most widely blamed and hated. Witnesses said at least one speaker was taken away by plainclothes police, and that the students dispersed peacefully soon after that. Soldiers and police armed with automatic weapons sealed off the streets around the campus. Security forces detained about a dozen foreign journalists who had just left the campus, and forced them to line up against a wall, according to one American in the group. ``Guns were in our faces,'' the American said on condition of anonymity. He said the security officials knocked Los Angeles Times correspondent David Holley to the ground and hit his wife, Fumio, before allowing the group to leave. The Holleys later were detained again but released after 15 minutes. Earlier Sunday, three Chinese made small, public protests on the edges of Tiananmen Square, which last year's protesters occupied for weeks. One man approached a Canadian Broadcasting Co. television crew and tried to display a protest poster. Police immediately dragged him away, as he shouted to bystanders in Chinese, ``Rise up.'' The Canadian reporters said they were able to read only the opening words of his poster: ``To all foreign journalists, we have invented a new philosophy ...'' Hours later, someone threw handfuls of white paper money _ a traditional offering to the dead _ from a car as it drove past the square. Police immediately tried to shoo away bystanders and pick up the paper. Police also took into custody a woman who stuffed an 18-page political essay into the pocket of a West German TV reporter. The small protests came despite the heaviest security in Beijing since martial law was lifted in January. Thousands of police and soldiers were stationed throughout the city to discourage commemoration of the crackdown. Tiananmen Square, the symbolic heart of Beijing, was closed to the public and encircled by paramilitary police. Soldiers loudly practiced martial arts next to the square. Last year's pro-democracy movement began in April with marches by Beijing students and grew into a nationwide movement involving millions of workers, intellectuals and some peasants. Troops and tanks rolled into central Beijing on the night of June 3 and retook Tiananmen Square. The attack lasted well into June 4 and was countered by civilians throwing gasoline bombs. When it ended, Beijing's streets looked like a war zone, strewn with burned tanks, army jeeps and buses. Thousands of people were arrested nationwide in the months that followed and many remain jailed without charge. Since then, only a few isolated protests have been attempted, although anger over the army attack remains widespread. Chinese officials gathered Sunday in the Great Hall of the People adjoining Tiananmen Square to commemorate another anniversary _ 150 years since the 1840 Opium War with Britain. The Communist Party regards the war as the start of foreign imperialist aggression against China. In a park in western Beijing, police broke up a crowd of about 40 Chinese at the English Corner, where people studying English gather each Sunday morning to practice. The police took five people away for questioning.

DOC.HEAD: Social Democrats Vote to Disband
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to RECAST, raise reference to lack of members and last month's election. SUBS 3rd graf from bottom, `The national...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with comment from party activist.
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the centrist Social Democratic Party voted to disband Sunday because of waning electoral fortunes, only nine years after it was founded in a dramatic challenge to Britain's established political order. ``If we did nothing else, we showed the importance of standing by your principles and policies which you think are in the best interest of the country,'' said leader David Owen after the national committee reached its decision. Owen helped form the party in 1981 to offer voters a centrist alternative to the Conservative Party and then-increasingly leftist Labor Party. But party membership had dwindled to only 6,000 members and in a parliamentary election last month was even beaten by a spoof party. Labor, led by Neil Kinnock, has abandoned its support for unilateral nuclear disarmament, unveiled a more centrist platform last month and recent polls show it leads Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives. The Social Democratic Party's national committee voted 17-5 to disband. In a statement, it said: ``This is a very sad day for us and for many others who have campaigned for the SDP and believe in the values of social democracy.'' Owen and his two fellow members of Parliament, John Cartwright and Rosie Barnes, will continue to sit in the House of Commons as Independent Social Democrats. Owen and three other former Cabinet ministers broke with the Labor Party in January 1981 and formed the Social Democratic Party two months later. Unable to break through the Conservative-Labor grip on power alone, the new party fought the 1983 and 1987 general elections as the Alliance with the established centrist Liberal Party. After winning only 22 of the 650 parliamentary districts in 1987, a majority of the membership of the two parties agreed to merge as the Social and Liberal Democrats. Owen and loyal supporters opposed to the merger remained Social Democrats. In a special election last month to fill a vacant parliamentary seat, the Social Democratic Party placed seventh out of eight candidates and was beaten by the spoof Monster Raving Loony Party. Owen said he had no plans, ``at this stage at least'' to rejoin the Labor Party, where he served as foreign secretary from 1977-79 and was seen as a potential prime minister. He said he thought the majority of the party's members would not join another party. ``There is a big unfinished agenda,'' he said. ``There will be a lot of people who will feel there is nobody they can vote for with full-hearted conviction now.'' Owen's principal critic within the party, John Martin, said, ``The party had become a burden to Dr. Owen. He is pleased not to have it.'' Martin said he would want to call the party activists together to see what they would want to do, but he could not say how they would react. Owen said the party was not short of money ``but we are very short of members.'' ``We have been pretending to do rather more than we have been able to do,'' Mrs. Barnes said. ``We cannot pretend to be a democratically based party with a membership now of just over 6,000.''

DOC.HEAD: Havel Denounces Terrorism After Bomb Blast in Prague
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel called for a tough stance against terrorists Sunday, one day after a bomb explosion injured 19 people on a downtown square in the capital. ``I consider it very important to show a strong hand, to show that freedom and democracy are not understood by us as a situation when everybody can act as they please,'' Havel said in a national radio interview from his country home at Lany, about 25 miles west of Prague. On Saturday afternoon, a bomb in a plastic bag exploded on Old Town Square, injuring tourists and children enjoying a concert as well as other passers-by. The police say they still don't know who placed the bomb, but political leaders and others believe the attack was meant to disrupt Czechoslovakia's transition to democracy. General elections are set for Friday and Saturday. ``The fact that it happened such a short time before the elections is a clear indication that one of the probable culprits is somebody from the circles of enemies of this power, and such enemies must be clearly shown they do not stand a chance,'' Havel told the radio without elaborating. Saturday's attack also drew strong condemnation from the country's political leaders. ``Democracy ... cannot be stopped,'' said Jan Urban, leader of the Civic Forum, in a statement released by the official CTK news agency Sunday. ``I am convinced that on behalf of all honest Communist Party members, I can express my jusified indignation,'' said Vasil Mohorita, chairman of the Czechoslovak Communist Party. Czechoslovakia's transition to democracy had been virtually without violence. The non-Communist government took over in December after the country ousted its Communist leaders last year when a wave of democratic revolutions gripped Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Survivors Dazed By Scope of Destruction
With AM-Midwest Storms, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A bride and four of her bridesmaids, all registered nurses, went from celebrating the wedding to tending the wounded when a tornado smashed through town. The reception for newly married Stacy and Clifford White was under way Saturday night at the Moose Lodge when ``the wind went to whipping and rolling,'' said Wilma Tuttle, one of the 250 wedding guests. ``It got where you couldn't see hardly anything at all then. It was just real black and a lot of lightning,'' said Ms. Tuttle. ``I was standing over there at the back door. And all of a sudden it just sounded like like a big train roar.'' The twisters killed eight people in Indiana _ six of them in or near Petersburg _ and one in Illinois. Jim Shoultz, the bride's father, yelled a warning, and most of the guests rushed into the basement before it hit. But after it was over, guests went out and found an injured elderly woman in the yard and and elderly man, his head bleeding, in a nearby home. Ms. White, 22, immediately began helping the two victims, her father said. She was helped by four bridesmaids, who also were nurses. Linen tablecloths were ripped up and used for bandages. ``They all worked in their wedding dresses,'' said Shoultz. ``They worked and worked on those people. Trees blocked all the streets and the emergency medical vehicles could not get through town.'' The two were both alive when they finally were loaded into ambulances, he said. The groom said the couple postponed their honeymoon until Monday. Down the street, the roof was torn off the Methodist church where the wedding ceremony was performed two hours earlier. ``Within six to 10 seconds, it was over,'' said caterer Jean Sollman. ``The total parking lot was demolished. It looked like a junkyard.'' On Sunday, strong sunlight revealed destruction that had been blurred by darkness, fear and confusion after the storms ripped through the town of 3,000 Saturday night, destroying or damaging at least 270 homes. ``Last night, all we could see were shadows, but we could tell half our house was gone,'' said Laura Britton. ``Now it looks even worse.'' Flooding that earned the town a state emergency declaration two weeks before now seemed trivial, she said. Hundreds of people wandered through town, staring at piles of bricks and twisted metal where homes and stores had stood. ``Right after it happened, you couldn't see anything,'' said Keith Burch, whose home was damaged. ``Power was out. People were screaming. Power lines were all across the road like cobwebs.'' Chris Anderson and about 300 other musicians were in a building at Petersburg's Horonady Park when a twister hit. Anderson, who plays a mandolin, was next in line to perform in the Indiana State Picking and Fiddling Contest. ``Someone ran in and said, `Everyone hit the floor!''' Anderson said. ``Then it hit. Doors blew open. Windows broke.'' Anderson said he knew of no serious injuries at the park, although more than 50 trees were scattered and cars were smashed. Trooper Vinnie Gieselman was dispatched to Petersburg to check downed power lines during the storm. He was in his patrol car when he saw a tornado. ``It was like one massive wall coming at me,'' he said. ``I grabbed my jacket and covered my head. It was a rough ride.'' Gieselman's crippled car, the back window shattered by a tree limb, was towed out of Petersburg on Sunday. It passed people picking through the debris of dozens of homes where few belongings remained in one piece. Many residents sat on battered porches, unsure what to do next. There was no electricity and most homes were without phone service or plumbing. The Red Cross handed out food and drinking water. Gary Ferrier stood alone on the collapsed porch of his 122-year-old Victorian home. A fourth of his roof was gone. In his front yard, a hand-lettered sign said ``Gone With the Wind.'' ``We're keeping our sense of humor and looking at the bright side of things,'' Ferrier said. ``What else can you do?''

DOC.HEAD: Farm Visit Canceled; Family to Meet Gorbachevs at Airport
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with plans, RECASTS first 10 grafs, picking up into 10th graf pvs, ``The agriculture economy.''
DOC.TEXT: Tired and behind schedule, Mikhail Gorbachev passed up a chance Sunday to drop in on a picture-perfect farm in the American heartland. But his loss was another's gain. Farmers Richard and Cecilia Brand said the food they planned to serve the the Gorbachevs would instead be donated to a homeless shelter in St. Paul. ``As a farmer we've been disappointed before,'' said Brand. ``Obviously we're disappointed. But all our friends and family have been great. It's been a lot of fun.'' The Soviet leader had requested the 25-minute visit to a family farm as part of his 6{-hour swing through the Twin Cities area. The Brands and their neighbors put in a lot of work for the brief stop-by at the property 45 minutes south of Minneapolis. They spruced up the farmhouse and barnyard, and workers using a grader smoothed 3{ miles of road leading to the Brand farm from the nearest tarred road. But after Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, landed in Minneapolis in the early afternoon, running almost a half-hour late, the Soviet president scratched the farm visit from their itinerary, according to Anne Edwards, a spokeswoman for the planners of the Minneapolis visit. ``He's just tired,'' U.S. Sen. Rudy Boschwitz said in a television interview. ``I think he won't get to San Francisco until after midnight.'' Instead of the cozy gathering around a picnic table that had been proposed, the Brands and their family were invited to meet the Gorbachevs on the airport tarmac just before their departure. ``We're going to make it a very special occasion,'' said Paul Ridgeway, lead U.S. advance coordinator for the Minnesota visit. ``President and Mrs. Gorbachev plan to spend time on the tarmac visiting with them. They're very sorry about this.'' Neighbor Dick Nielsen's property on Sunday morning played host to trailers that carried sheriff's patrol horses, and news photographers worked from a temporary darkroom in his family's garage. Other neighbors let officials park cars in their driveways. The agriculture economy has rebounded in much of the Midwest following several disastrous years in the early to mid-1980s that forced thousands of farmers off their land. In the past few years, farm land values have increased and debt has decreased. The Brands had said they wanted to show Gorbachev a ``typical American farm,'' although what's typical isn't clear in these days of large-scale corporate farm operations. The Brands, who run their 240-acre farm with their two sons, milk 75 cows and raise alfalfa, corn and soybeans. In all they have 250 cows. The couple previously has been host to foreign visitors, which they believe is due in part to their proximity to the Twin Cities and easy access to the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. State Agriculture Department officials suggested the couple for the Gorbachev trip.

DOC.HEAD: Special Election Begins in Mexico; Opposition Cries Foul
DOC.TEXT: For the second time in six months, city residents voted for a mayor Sunday, but the opposition claimed the balloting had been rigged, as was an earlier, annulled tally. Opposition leaders said the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party was driving voters to the polls with fake documents and had taken thousands of opposition supporters off voter registration lists. Allegations of electoral fraud have frequently been made against the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has controlled the government since the party's formation in 1929. Party leaders have pledged to end fraud and corruption within the party. The special election in Uruapan, a city of 450,000 that is the second largest in the western state of Michoacan, was being held because the results of the Dec. 3 vote were annulled because of charges of fraud. Rep. Jose Gonzalez Morfin of the conservative National Action Party said Sunday that his party's supporters had seen a pickup truck without license plates and government trucks carrying people with fake documents to vote. Reporters observed at least one such truck that appeared to be carrying on such an operation at one precinct. At the same time, people carrying voting credentials at the same precinct were turned away when electoral officials said their names did not appear on the voting list. No electoral officials were immediately available to comment on the charges of fraud. Members of the center-left Democratic Revolutionary Party and National Action Party had said before the voting that many of their supporters had been eliminated from the rolls. Uruapan has been governed by a provisional administration since the state legislature canceled December's vote count. Juan Antonio Chavez Mendoza, a Democratic Revolutionary member, said Saturday the governing party distributed 5,000 voting credentials to its own members rather than the rightful owners. He said some were given to people from other parts of the state who would be brought in to vote. The governing party has denied the allegations. Jose Rosario Torres Ramos, the local Democratic Revolutionary chairman, said the contest is so close that a few hundred votes could make a difference in the outcome. Uruapan, 200 miles west of Mexico City, is one of more than 20 cities where the Democratic Revolutionary Party challenged victories claimed by the governing party in December. The party's activists seized city halls in 21 communities around the state after those elections. Army troops ousted the protesters with tear gas and fire hoses four months later. No injuries were reported. Michoacan is the birthplace of former presidential candidate Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, who forged the Democratic Revolutionary Party from an alliance of opposition parties. Cardenas claims that fraud caused his defeat by Carlos Salinas de Gortari in the 1988 presidential race.

DOC.HEAD: Surprising Warning by Gorbachev to Israel at Windup
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS two grafs after 7th pvs, Conceivably these ...., to elaborate on ideas being considered for resolution of German question. Picks up 8th pvs, Other U.S. ....
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ended summit talks on Sunday promising to work with President Bush toward a solution to Germany's military future but sternly warning Israel and independence-minded Lithuanians on other issues. Gorbachev said he had surveyed with Bush ``new possible perspectives'' on Germany. One of them, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said, might be a ``political agreement'' between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact. ``I cannot say that we have reached agreement, but that does not mean that our efforts were futile,'' Gorbachev said of his dogged _ and unsuccessful _ campaign to persuade Bush that a unified Germany should not be aligned against the Soviet Union. Bush, at their joint news conference, insisted that a united Germany in NATO ``would be stabilizing'' and said he did not think his differences with Gorbachev on the issue had been narrowed during their four days of talks. But the two leaders parted amicably. ``The atmosphere and the results of this meeting make it possible for us to speak really of a new phase of cooperation,'' Gorbachev said. Baker will pursue the German question with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze while they attend a European security conference on human rights this week in Copenhagen, Denmark, and again, in Berlin, later in the month. ``Conceivably there could be some sort of a political agreement of some sort'' to help the East and Central Europeans accept German membership in NATO, Baker said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' ``There are some ideas'' for resolving the German question, Baker said. He said those ideas came from the United States, the Soviet Union and the NATO allies. Among those were many that have been previously mentioned: a more political role for NATO and the plan, forwarded by West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, to keep NATO troops out of territory now part of East Germany. ``We'll keep wrestling with it,'' he said. Other U.S. officials said last week that Gorbachev had proposed creation of a new all-European council to consider military questions arising from the impending merger of East Germany and West Germany. Among them would be the size of the German army. On two other summit issues _ Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union and the drive for independence in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia _ Gorbachev took a tough stand in reply to reporters' questions. Having permitted Jewish emigration to soar to an all-time high _ some 20,000 exit permits were issued in May _ Gorbachev aligned himself with Arab leaders who, he said, had protested in ``acute terms'' the continuing settlement of Jews by Israel on the West Bank and in Gaza. If ``certain conclusions'' are not reached in Jerusalem, the Soviet leader said, ``we must give further thought to it in terms of what we can do with issuing permits for exit.'' Bush, meanwhile, reiterated U.S. opposition to further settlements on the lands surrendered by Jordan and Egypt in their 1967 war with Israel. ``I will try to persuade the government of Israel that it is counterproductive,'' he said. Baker said the Soviets had told him last month in Moscow and on other occasions that they might suspend Jewish emigration if refugees are permitted to live on the West Bank and in Gaza. ``They have a great deal more trouble with that than we do,'' Baker said. While the Bush administration is opposed to the settlements it firmly supports Jewish emigration, he said. Bush said he would not consider lowering U.S. tariffs on Soviet imports until the Soviet parliament enacts a new law establishing emigration as a right. On the Baltics, an area of sharp disagreement although Bush declined to let it stand in the way of a new trade pact with Moscow, the Soviet leader insisted that the drive for independence be channeled through constitutional means. Any other approach, Gorbachev said, ``leads only to an impasse.'' ``Our Constitution has recorded the right for each people to make a choice for self-determination up to and including secession,'' he said. And, he added, the sovereign rights of the Soviet republics were being expanded. Lithuanians and other people ``trying to resolve the problem by different methods, without due regard for the Constitution, leads to exacerbation, aggravation and confrontation,'' Gorbachev said. ``This is not beneficial either for people, for their families, or for the economy, or for the overall atmosphere in our country.'' Bush, in turn, called U.S.-Soviet differences over Lithuania ``one of the thorns in the side of an overall relationship.'' After Gorbachev left, a senior U.S. official said the Soviet leader was ``in full accord'' with Bush that Germans had the right to make a decision about NATO membership by virtue of the 1975 Helsinki agreement signed by 35 nations. ``It's the first time he has done that with the president,'' said the official, who sought out reporters while insisting he not be quoted by name or be otherwise identified. ``He said that he agreed that this was up to the German people to decide,'' the official said. ``We'll have to see what that means,'' Gorbachev, speaking at the news conference on what he called ``external aspects'' of German unification _ meaning how the new country would relate to other European nations _ said the two sides had clarified their positions and ``we will continue our discussion in order to find a mutually acceptable solution.''

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Backs Gov't Reform But Reserves Right to Criticize
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, who has in the past called for quicker economic reform, said Sunday he nevertheless backs the government's drive to introduce free markets. He tempered his support, however, by saying he reserves the right to offer constructive criticism. His remarks came as a rival but less powerful union renewed its attacks on the government's program to dismantle the centrally planned economy. Delegates at the rival OPZZ union's congress put the blame for the country's problems on the reform plan. OPZZ was the Communist government's sanctioned union before Solidarity was legalized last year and a Solidarity-led administration took power. Walesa, addressing supporters Sunday after Mass in the Baltic port of Gdansk, declared, ``Solidarity firmly supports the reform activities of the government. It will support them _ but not uncritically.'' Walesa was speaking to a crowd of about 1,500 people in the courtyard of St. Brygida's Roman Catholic church. The government's radical economic reform plan has achieved its first major objective of ending three-digit inflation since the program took effect Jan. 1. The plan slashed subsidies to state-run enterprises, eliminated most price controls and introduced a tight wage policy. More than 400,000 people have registered for umemployment benefits. The government has sought assistance from the West to help make the complex transition, but the amount offered so far has not met expectations. ``Let us remember that we can count only on ourselves. Nothing has come out of our alliances with the West, like with our friendship with the East,'' Walesa said Sunday. At the final day of the OPZZ congress in Warsaw on Sunday, miner Rajmund Moric declared that ``if the government's position does not change by midyear, a protest action will be needed nationwide.'' The union says the government's program is causing too much unemployment and making living standards decline. It also objects to plans to privatize the state enterprises, where many of its members work.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Gorbachev End Summit in Glowing Terms Despite Differences
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB 3rd graf, The Soviet ..., with three grafs to give Gorbachev remarks in Minneapolis; picks up 4th pvs: ``We've moved ...''; ^By TERENCE HUNT
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev proclaimed ``an atmosphere of growing trust'' Sunday at the close of their four-day summit. They left unsolved nagging differences on German unity and independence for Lithuania. The leaders parted with smiles and warm handshakes and a decision to meet on a regular basis _ perhaps annually. The Soviet president invited Bush to Moscow, a state visit that may take place before year's end. The Soviet president and his wife jetted off to meet with business and farm leaders in Minneapolis and an overnight stop in San Francisco. ``I personally believe that this summit will go down in history as a summit of hope and optimism,'' Gorbachev said at the beginning of his meeting in Minneapolis. ``I think that two or three days later or two or three weeks later, we will really begin to understand what this meeting has produced.'' On Monday, Gorbachev has a reunion with Ronald Reagan, and holds a first-ever meeting with the president of South Korea. ``We've moved a long, long way from the depths of the Cold War,'' Bush said at a wrapup news conference, sitting alongside Gorbachev at the same mahogany table where they sealed agreements Friday to slash long-range nuclear weapons, halt production of chemical weapons, and lift trade barriers against Moscow. The news conference was broadcast live in America and across the Soviet Union, where mounting political and economic problems await Gorbachev on his return. Gorbachev said the two leaders compared differences in ``an atmosphere of frankness, a constructive atmosphere, an atmosphere of growing trust.'' Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev, who cemented a warm relationship over the four days, sat beside each other at the news conference, listening with earphones to the translations of their husband's comments. Despite the rosy assessments, stubborn problems persisted. Bush said Gorbachev offered no assurances that he would ease his economic stranglehold on Lithuania, the Baltic republic struggling for freedom. The U.S. leader said the question of Baltic independence was ``one of the thorns in the side of an overall relationship.'' As for Gorbachev's objections to a united Germany belonging to NATO, Bush said, ``I'm not sure we narrowed them.'' Gorbachev said the European questions were matters of ``the highest level of strategy.'' He said of Germany, without elaboration, ``We're not going to put spokes in the wheel.'' Separately, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said he will explore a ``political agreement'' between NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact to bridge the differences over a unified Germany. He was skeptical of an idea from a Gorbachev adviser that the Soviet Union become a member of NATO, the 16-nation Western alliance. Overseas, leaders of the two Germanys said the summit improved prospects for unifying their countries and boosted chances for disarmament. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher pronounced the meeting ``a great success.'' East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere hailed ``new and very different ideas'' about stabilizing European security. Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze will take up the German question on Tuesday at a Copenhagen human rights meeting and then again later in the month at the so-called two-plus-four unification talks. These talks involve the two Germanys and the four victors of World War II _ the United States, Soviet Union, France and Britain. With impassioned words, Gorbachev said he was obliged to speak for the 27 million Soviets killed in German-provoked World War II. ``It's not a matter of pride but of justice _ supreme justice. ... We have a moral right.'' The news conference was sprinkled with moments of humor. When a Soviet journalist asked Gorbachev about his problems with political nemesis Boris Yeltsin, he replied, ``I don't think you have chosen the best place for clarifying our internal problems. But c'est la vie, as they say.'' On the contentious issue of Lithuania, Bush said he did not link trade benefits for Moscow with a relaxation of pressure on the Baltic republic. The only price, he said, was passage of a Soviet law protecting Jewish emigration. ``That's it,'' he said. Yet, Baker acknowledged it would be ``very difficult'' to win congressional approval of a trade treaty as long as the Soviets crack down on Lithuania. And White House chief of staff John Sununu said, ``There is going to be linkage with a whole host of issues.'' Gorbachev demanded that Lithuania follow a constitutionally prescribed route toward freedom, including a referendum. After that, he said, it would take ``no fewer than five or seven years'' to sort things out in what he called ``this divorce proceeding.'' On Germany, Bush said he and Gorbachev agreed it was up to the Germans to decide which military alliance they join after unification, in accordance with a 35-nation agreement known as the Helsinki Final Act. A senior administration official said the U.S. side attached significance to Gorbachev's agreement on that point, the first time the Soviet leader had done so. Nevertheless, the official said, ``I didn't say they're buying our side. We're hopeful this reflects some movement.'' Gorbachev said he had offered many options on the question of Germany. ``It seems to me there are some points the American side has noticed,'' he said. Soviet spokesman Gennadi Gerasimov ridiculed NATO, saying that it must be changed. ``These letters may stand for `navies, aircraft, tanks _ obsolete.'' Gorbachev used the news conference with Bush to warn Israel that he would ``give thought'' to suspending the issuance of exit permits for Soviet Jews if they continue to be settled on the disputed West Bank or in Gaza. Although Bush is pressing Moscow for free emigration rights, he noted that the United States opposes new settlements. The summit ended on a friendly note. In a prepared statement opening the news conference, Bush said they had talked with ``candor and openness.'' Gorbachev responded with a paean to Bush's statesmanship. ``This is the kind of person to do business with,'' Gorbachev said. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the two leaders were alike in some ways. ``When they debate across a table, they see a mirror image. They even have a similar sense of humor. They make fun of things, they tease each other,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Phones Mrs. Thatcher About Summit
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Sunday night that his four-day summit with Mikhail S. Gorbachev had gone well and they had a good rapport, the prime minister's office said. In a 20-minute telephone conversation, Bush gave Mrs. Thatcher an account of his discussions with the Soviet president, and the two discussed the implications for Mrs. Thatcher's trip to the Soviet Union at the end of the week, a spokesman for her 10 Downing St. office said. Mrs. Thatcher departs Thursday for Moscow on a four-day visit, during which she will meet with Gorbachev for the fifth time in six years. Mrs. Thatcher, after her first meeting with the Soviet leader in London in 1984, described him as a man she could do business with. Bush and Gorbachev concluded their talks in Washington on Sunday, and at a news conference the Soviet leader said the two men had compared differences in ``an atmosphere of frankness, a constructive atmosphere, an atmosphere of growing trust.'' During an international radio phone-in on the BBC World Service earlier in the day, Mrs. Thatcher expressed her admiration for Gorbachev. ``I think President Gorbachev is a quite remarkable president and a remarkable person. I am a great fan,'' she said. ``When you think that for the greater part of this century the old type of Communism has held sway. .... He had the courage and vision to say `It is not working'.'' Mrs. Thatcher also said she was impressed that, unlike other Soviet leaders, Gorbachev was willing to talk freely about a whole range of issues.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Front Brings Severe Weather to Northeast after Spawning Tornadoes
DOC.TEXT: A powerful storm system crossing the Midwest spawned more than 100 tornadoes before bringing some severe weather to the Northeast Sunday. Across Indiana, officials reported eight dead and at least 150 people injured Saturday night in the state's worst tornado outbreak since 1974. The storms left 24 cities in 15 counties with significant damage. Officials tracked about 50 tornado touchdowns during a four-hour period. In Illinois a tornado destroyed or damaged scores of houses and killed one woman, and a 10-year-old boy drowned in a storm-swollen river in Milwaukee. A cold front racing across the lower Great Lakes region and the upper Ohio Valley brought thunderstorms to northern Vermont and upstate New York, while showers and thunderstorms ahead of the front extended from northeastern Texa through central Mississippi and northern Georgia into southern West Virginia. The thunderstorms produced locally heavy rains from southern Arkansas through northern Alabama to eastern Kentucky. Heavier rainfall totals for the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included nearly four inches at El Dorado, Ark., and three inches at Texarkana Ark. Showers and thunderstorms fell on much of Florida. Drizzle and scattered showers stretched across Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Upper Michigan, and showers associated with a cold front crossing the Pacific Northwest were scattered across Washington state, northern Idaho and western Oregon. Strong, gusty winds were circulating about the deep low pressure system centered over Upper Michigan. On Sunday morning, wind gusts reached to 52 mph at Chicago, and to 56 at Milwaukee. Strong, southerly winds ahead of an advancing cold front prevailed across the East and temperatures rose to the 70s and 80s as far north as New England, despite mostly cloudy skies. Clouds and light rain in the north-central United States were keeping afternoon temperatures in the 40s and upper 30s across the upper Mississippi Valley and much of the northern Plains. Sunny skies prevailed Sunday afternoon from California to the Plains, and much of the Ohio Valley and mid-Mississippi Valley in the wake of the severe weather outbreak on Saturday. Temperatures rose into the 80s and 90s across the south-central United States, with readings soaring to nearly 100 degrees in the desert Southwest. The nation's temperatures at 2 p.m. EDT ranged from 37 degrees at Houghton and Marquette, Mich., to 107 at Palm Springs, Calif. The low Sunday morning was 28 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: President, Family Have Chinese Food after Soviet Summit
DOC.TEXT: President Bush relaxed after four days of meetings with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev by having Sunday dinner with family members at Bush's favorite Chinese restaurant. Bush and his wife, Barbara, drove in a rainstorm to this Virginia suburb of Washington for dinner at the Peking Gourmet Inn. The president and Mrs. Bush shared a table with son Marvin, daughter-in-law Margaret and grandchildren Marshall, 4, and Walker, an infant. The family ate in privacy behind a partition. But at one point Mrs. Bush emerged to get Ranger, a puppy, out of the presidential limousine. ``We're trying to get Ranger home,'' Bush later explained as he came out of the restaurant. The dog had spent the weekend at the White House with its mother, Millie. It belongs to Marvin Bush and his family, who live in Alexandria, Va.

DOC.HEAD: Sources: Terrorist Threat Forces Scaled-Down U.S. Military Exercise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th pvs, `A U.S. ...' to UPDATE with hometown of serviceman. Pickup 10th pvs, `On Friday...'
DOC.TEXT: Recent murders of American soldiers by Communist rebels and new threats have prompted the U.S. Air Force to scale back a training exercise to keep all personnel on base, U.S. sources said Sunday. The latest killing of a U.S. serviceman came Saturday night near Subic Naval Base, but American officials said theft _ not politics _ was the motive. About 1,000 troops had been expected to take part in the two-week military exercise, which was to begin Monday at Clark Air Base, Air Force officials said. But the number was reduced to about 850 so that all personnel could be housed on the base, 50 miles north of Manila. In Honolulu, Air Force spokesman Maj. James Pasierb said the reduction would not affect the scope of the operation, the final phase of this year's Cope Thunder series of exercises. He claimed the reductions were not prompted by Communist threats. ``I want to make it clear that we are not scaling back on the exercise because of any terroristic activity,'' he said. But sources at Clark, speaking on condition of anonymity, said security was the primary consideration. Last month, Communist rebels killed two American airmen near Clark and vowed more attacks until all U.S. troops leave the Philippines. A U.S. Navy lieutenant was fatally stabbed Saturday near Subic, but officials said the motive was robbery and not politically related. The Navy identified the victim as Richard E. Brown, 33, of Spring Valley, N.Y. On Friday, U.S. officials imposed new travel restrictions on the 20,300 troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents stationed at Clark, citing the ``current threat conditions.'' Clark Air Base is in an area of central Luzon island, a stronghold of the New People's Army, which has been waging a 21-year insurgency to establish a Marxist state. During the six previous Cope Thunder exercises this year, hundreds of airmen on temporary duty were housed in civilian hotels near the base because of a shortage of room on the base. The policy was changed, however, after the rebels killed airmen John Raven and James Green in front of their hotel on May 13, the day before U.S. and Philippine negotiators opened talks on the future of the bases. Raven and Green were on temporary duty from Kunsan Air Base in South Korea because their unit was taking part in Cope Thunder training. After the killings, hundreds of airmen were moved back onto the base and some were housed in the gym because of the housing shortage. This week's exercises also will include U.S. units from Japan and South Korea. U.S. officials say training facilities in the Clark area, including the nearby Crowe Valley firing range, are far superior to those available in Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEAD: British Foreign Secretary Urges Israeli Talks With Palestinians
With AM-Summit-Israel
DOC.TEXT: British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd urged Israel on Sunday to agree to direct peace negotiations with the Palestinians, and he warned of large-scale violence without a Middle East settlement. Speaking at the end of a two-day visit to Saudi Arabia, Hurd called on Washington to maintain its ``constructive engagement'' as part of a four-point plan to reactivate the stalled Middle East peace process. ``A tremor of danger may shake the region and if things drift further, we risk a damaging escalation of violence,'' he said at a news conference. Hurd suggested that a U.N. representative make a fact-finding visit to the Israeli-occupied territories and report back to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. ``The security of Israel cannot be ensured by ignoring the existence of those whose territories her forces now occupy,'' he said. Hurd's suggestion points to a less binding alternative to a three-member investigative team considered by the U.N. Security Council last week. Britain and the other members of the Security Council backed the resolution, but the United States used its veto power to block it. Hurd's plan to reactivate the peace process proposed: ``First, the United States needs to maintain its constructive engagement in the search for peace. ``Second, there is room for a greater degree of international involvement to which the European Community has consistently given its support. Some progress could be made by a representative of the U.N. Secretary General visiting the occupied territories and reporting on the situation there. ``Third, the PLO should not only reaffirm its denunciation of terrorism but respect it strictly in practice. ``Fourth, an Israeli government needs to carry forward the peace process by entering into dialogue with representative Palestinians.'' Hurd welcomed the Soviet Union's more liberal emigration policy, but termed the settlement of Soviet Jews in Israel's occupied territories as ``unjust'' and ``illegal.'' ``The Arab world is deeply worried by the prospect of Soviet Jews settling in occupied territories. It is not right to correct one injustice and impose another,'' Hurd said. In another development Sunday, a U.N. delegation seeking a nuclear-free zone in the Middle East began a two-day visit to Israel, which is reportedly the only country in the region with atomic weapons. The three-man delegation was named in 1988 to prepare a report for the U.N. secretary-general on ways to advance nuclear disarmament in the Middle East. The team has already visited Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Iran and Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Declines Israeli Invitation To Visit Occupied Territories
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Gorbachev declining visit, response to warning by U.S. Jewish leaders. Edits to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit-Issues, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A government minister on Sunday asked Mikhail S. Gorbachev to visit the occupied territories to see himself that Israel has no policy of settling Jewish immigrants there, but the Soviet president said the time was not right. The invitation was extended by Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz after Gorbachev warned Israel he would consider suspending exit permits for Soviet Jews if they continue to be settled in the territories. Gorbachev, in Minneapolis after wrapping up his four-day summit meeting with President Bush in Washington earlier in the day, was asked if he would be interested in traveling to Israel. ``I will be frank, the time has not yet come to go there,'' he said in Russian. ``Let the leaders of Israel think about what has been said today in Washington so they don't turn out to be the only people in the world who don't understand.'' President Bush, who joined Gorbachev at a concluding news conference in Washington, repeated that the United States is opposed to further settlements in the lands captured by Israel from the Arabs in the 1967 Middle East War. ``I will try to persuade the government of Israel that it is counterproductive,'' Bush said. Avi Pazner, spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said Israel was not directing Soviet immigrants to the Gaza Strip and West Bank. ``It is well known that Israel does not have a policy of directing the new immigrants from the Soviet Union or elsewhere to the territories,'' Pazner said. ``The new immigrants ... have the freedom to choose where they want to live.'' Pazner said only a ``few hundred people'' had chosen to live in the occupied lands. He said the Arab states were using them to mount an offensive against Jewish immigration from the Soviet Union to Israel. In Washington, Gorbachev had said the Soviet Union ``is being bombarded by a lot of criticism'' from Arab countries regarding Israel's immigration policies. Presidents Hafez Assad of Syria and Hosni Mubarak of Egypt raised their objections ``in acute terms,'' he said. Gorbachev said that if Israel does not heed appeals to keep Jewish immigrants from settling in the occupied lands, ``we must give further thought to it, in terms with what we can do with issuing permits for exit.'' Some in the Soviet Union, he said, have suggested that the government ``postpone issuing permits for exit, to put it off'' until Israel provides the necessary assurances. Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union is at an all-time high. About 35,000 Soviet Jews arrived in Israel this year, and the figure is expected to reach as high as 150,000. About 1 million Soviets are seeking permission to emigrate. Israeli officials say only 200 Soviet Jews have settled in the occupied areas, joining 70,000 Jewish settlers who live there amid 1.7 million Palestinians. Peretz, who said he was authorized by the government to extend the invitation to Gorbachev, asserted that Soviet Jews who settled in the occupied lands this year and last ``did so on the basis of family reunification.'' Deputy Prime Minister David Levy said Gorbachev's warning violated his own policy of extending greater freedom to Soviet citizens. ``The Soviet Union is changing direction and it cannot be that only regarding Jews it would take a step that leads it backward and not forward, to progress and freedom,'' he said. The Soviet leader's remarks also were sharply criticized by U.S. Jewish leaders. Malcolm Hoenlein, executive director of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, said the comments were doubtlessly ``a response to the unrelenting Arab campaign to halt Jewish emigration.'' ``But even to suggest a restriction of Jewish emigration to Israel is unacceptable.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Plunges into Crowds in St. Paul
With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev threw police for a loop and onlookers into a frenzy Sunday by repeatedly making unscripted plunges into crowds to shake hands and chat. The Soviet president left his limousine to greet crowds before a luncheon at the governor's mansion, crossed the street after lunch to the delight of another group and walked the street a third time near the St. Paul Cathedral. One stop he didn't make disappointed both admirers and protesters: His motorcade didn't even slow down during its 45-second trip around the state Capitol, where an estimated 6,000 people had waited seven hours in damp and chilly weather. Earlier, through an interpreter at one of his impromptu stops, Gorbachev told the crowd: ``Thank you all for your feelings. The Soviet people have just as much respect for American citizens as you do. I wish happiness and well-being to the people of Minnesota and this state.'' Gorbachev smiled broadly and nodded to the crowds, occasionally saying a few words. Supporters' shouts of ``Gorby! Gorby!'' mixed with jeers from protesters. Crowds held signs reading ``We love Mikhail, Raisa,'' ``Mr. Gorbachev is a Cool Dude'' and ``Give Gorbachev the Nobel Peace Prize.'' After lunch at the governor's mansion, Gorbachev waded into the throngs outside and walked more than a block. He talked for about two minutes with 11-year-old Brandon Peterson, but it was not immediately known what the two said. Gorbachev got back into his car, but had the motorcade stop again. Security ropes were either down or nonexistent, and police used loudspeakers to tell the crowd to back off the street. Gorbachev stuck his hand out his car window and waved at the throng outside the Capitol, but his face was only barely visible. Many people ran the length of the Capitol lawn, leaping hedges and jumping curbs, hoping for a better look. ``I was a little disappointed because he is one of the most important people that ever lived,'' said Helene Turnbull of Minneapolis. ``But it was worth the wait seeing all the excitement.'' ``It did go pretty fast,'' said Shelly Hanson, who, along with her husband, son, daughter and nephew, made a 2{-hour trip from Alexandria and then waited two hours for the motorcade to arrive. ``I think his actions proved he doesn't care about real people, that he only wants to meet business people,'' said Vivita Rozenbergs, a Minneapolis resident of Baltic ancestry. ``His actions speak louder than his words.''

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Lower in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold dropped 28 cents an ounce on Hong Kong markets Monday, opening at $360.52. It closed at $360.80 Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Reviews Student's Story of Tiananmen Square
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Li in London, comments. Pickup 5th pvs, `Li's book...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-China, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Novelist Salman Rushdie on Sunday praised a Chinese student's account of the Tiananmen Square repression as an important testament to ``beautiful and terrible'' events. Rushdie, who has been in hiding since Iranian religious leaders called for his death last year for alleged blasphemy of Islam in his novel ``The Satanic Verses,'' reviewed the book ``Moving the Mountain'' by Li Lu in the weekly Independent on Sunday. Li escaped from China one month after the army crackdown against pro-democracy students on June 3-4 last year in Beijing and is now studying in the United States. In London on Sunday he told an anniversary rally that the movement will rise again. In his review, Rushdie recalled the collapse of communist rule in Eastern Europe last year and said this weekend's anniversary of the crackdown on the pro-democracy students in Beijing was a ``time to remember that 1989 was a year not only of miracles but of horrors as well.'' Li's book, published in London by Macmillan, tells of his boyhood during China's Cultural Revolution. He was handed over to a coal miner's family to be brought up because his parents had been denounced as intellectuals. Li was a student at Nanjing University when he joined the students in Tiananmen Square. He became one of the leaders and just before the repression, married his girlfriend in the square. He left China but gives no details nor say if his bride went with him. Rushdie said in his review: ``No doubt, in time, there will be calmer, less hurried responses to the appalling events of last year in Beijing. No doubt other surviviors will emerge to tell us their stories. ``But Li Lu's book, rough and ready as it is, is an important one. He is the first witness to speak, and what he witnessed was beautiful and terrible, almost _ but not quite _ beyond words.'' Rushdie has remained in hiding since Iranian officials pronounced the death sentence Feb. 14, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Police Capture Planeload Of Cocaine
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Sunday seized a light airplane loaded with cocaine and arrested its pilot, who identified himself as a Colombian air force captain, police said. Police almost captured the plane at a refueling stop earlier in the day but were rebuffed by machete- and club-wielding residents after the pilot told them he was bringing in a shipment of cheese, police Capt. Carlos Munoz said. Police later captured pilot Leonardo Aragon Flores, the plane and more than 440 pounds of cocaine in the community of Aposentillo on the Nicaraguan side of the border with Honduras, Munoz said in an interview. He said Aragon identified himself as a Colombian air force captain and showed documents identifying him as such. The plane landed near Managua to refuel earlier in the day, where the residents had fought with police, Munoz said. Munoz said Aragon had told residents of the San Rafael del Sur community, 30 miles from Managua, that the plane contained a shipment of cheese. He said Aragon managed to fly the plane away, but police and soldiers arrested a crew member, 30-year-old Oscar Cardenas, who had left the plane to get gas. Munoz said Cardenas is a Colombian civilian. Aragon had apparently flown the Colombian-registered plane from Colombia and was on his way to Guatemala with the cocaine, which was contained in 16 bags, Munoz said. It landed in Aposentillo. Munoz said Aragon was carrying a revolver. Aragon was jailed in the western city of Leon, about 50 miles from Managua, Munoz said.

DOC.HEAD: Debris From Bridge Damages Cars; Injures Motorists
DOC.TEXT: Chunks of concrete plummetted from a bridge onto an interstate highway 75 feet below Sunday, damaging at least 20 vehicles and injuring three motorists. ``A rock came out of the sky, bounced off our hood and smashed the windshield,'' said motorist Laura Nizankiewicz. ``There was glass all over the car. My sister got a piece in her eye, and our arms were covered with little slivers.'' State Trooper W. Hughes said 20 vehicles received damage to hoods, roofs, windshields and bumpers as they passed on Interstate 376 under the city-owned bridge around 3:30 p.m. At least three people were injured, Hughes said. Two people were treated at the scene, and one woman was in stable condition at Presbyterian-University Hospital in Pittsburgh, he said. Al Neri, a spokesman for Mayor Sophie Masloff, said late Sunday city engineers weren't sure if the debris fell from the bridge or from collection nets placed under the span during the weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Observes Nuclear Safety Computers at Control Data
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT that Gorbachev did not say the computers were made necessary by Chernobyl and to ADD quote; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `Control Data ...'
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev got a first-hand look Sunday at $32 million worth of computers his country hopes will improve the safety of nuclear power plants. In remarks to a few hundred people at the headquarters of Control Data Corp., the Soviet president said he hopes the six Control Data computers the Soviets have agreed to buy will prevent another disaster like Chernobyl. ``We cannot really do without nuclear energy today,'' he said. ``This particular type of energy has a lot of advantages but it also has risks. ``What can we do to make it as safe as possible? This is something we must pursue, especially in the civilian sector. We do welcome and applaud this new step in our economic cooperation.'' Control Data was the final stop on the seven-hour visit to Minnesota by Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa. But Mrs. Gorbachev didn't accompany her husband as scheduled, instead extending her visit to a Minneapolis family. ``I was told your state is a closed state,'' Gorbachev said. ``Right now it is beginning to open toward the Soviet Union. See how fast things are changing?'' The six mainframe computers to be exported to the Soviet Union will be used as information banks to make decisions on handling accidents, performing maintenance, building new plants and decommissioning old ones, said Control Data executive Scott Harris. The Chernobyl accident in 1986 occurred while Soviet scientists were running a physical test on the plant, and it ``may have been possible to run that test as a mathematical model on a computer,'' Harris said. Earlier, Gerald R. Giombetti, vice president of international trade for Control Data, said the U.S. government has indicated it soon will approve export of the computers. The United States requires safeguards to ensure that the computers will be used strictly for their intended purpose, he said. The biggest concerns were raised by the Pentagon, Giombetti said. ``It's the fear of a dual use,'' he said. ``Even though it is a civilian application, the big concern is that this is at a nuclear site.'' Control Data has been doing business in the Soviet Union for more than 20 years. The first American-built mainframe in the USSR was a Cyber 1604, installed at the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research at Dubna in 1968. The deal was made during the thaw in U.S.-Soviet relations known as ``Ostpolitik.'' The pending sale of nuclear safety computers would be Control Data's first deal with the Soviet Union since 1979, when trade was restricted by President Carter after the Soviets invaded Afghanistan, Giombetti said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachevs to Observe Nuclear Safety Computers at Control Data
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to RECAST. Lead prospects uncertain; visit expected to end at 8:50 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: One purpose of Mikhail Gorbachev's visit to Minnesota was to inspect some merchandise _ $32 million in Control Data Corp. computers, to be used to improve the safety of Soviet nuclear power plants. The Soviet President and his wife, Raisa, hoped to make a brief swing through Control Data's headquarters as part of their 6{-hour visit to the Twin Cities. Although the company has slipped from the top ranks of the nation's computer makers in recent years, its more than 20-year history of commercial ties with the Soviets was believed to be a factor in the visit. The six mainframe computers are to be delivered to plant and research sites in four Soviet cities, said Gerald R. Giombetti, vice president of international trade for Control Data. They would be the most powerful computers ever exported to the Soviet Union. Giombetti said the U.S. government has indicated it will approve export of the computers soon. The United States requires safeguards to ensure the computers will be used for their intended purpose and not for military purposes, he said. ``We've had a lot of dialogue with the U.S. government at very high levels,'' said Giombetti, who noted the biggest concerns were voiced by the Defense Department. ``It's the fear of a dual use. Even though it is a civilian application, the big concern is that this is at a nuclear site.'' Control Data executives Scott Harris and Bill Selden said the machines wouldn't be used to run nuclear plants. Instead, they are to be used as easy-access information banks to make decisions on handling accidents, performing maintenance, building new plants and decommissioning old ones. Harris and Selden said the purchase was driven partly by the Chernobyl nuclear accident, which occurred while Soviet scientists were running a test on the plant. ``It may have been possible to run that test as a mathematical model on a computer,'' Harris said. Control Data has been doing business in the Soviet Union for more than 20 years. The first American-built mainframe in the U.S.S.R. was a Cyber 1604, installed at the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research at Dubna in 1968 during a thaw in U.S.-Soviet relations. The pending sale of nuclear safety computers would be Control Data's first deal with the Soviet Union since 1979, when President Carter imposed trade restrictions after the Soviets invaded Afghanistan, Giombetti said. Control Data also has agreed to sell the Soviets about $6 million worth of computer equipment for oil exploration. The Soviets have made this area a priority and Gorbachev announced an oil exploration agreement had been signed with Chevron Corp. during the Washington summit. Rick Berglund, a Control Data spokesman, said the approval process for the oil exploration equipment is just beginning. The equipment sales come at a time when Control Data is struggling to turn around years of losses and shift its business more toward computer services. The company lost a total of $1.4 billion in the second half of the 1980s and was forced to retrench, selling subsidiaries that made computer chips and disk drives and folding its supercomputer business. Computer products still make up the largest division at Control Data, but demand for the company's upper-range mainframes has declined in each of the past two years.

DOC.HEAD: China to Open First Futures Market in August
DOC.TEXT: China this summer will open what it says is the first futures market in a socialist country, an official newspaper reported. The market will open in August in the central city of Zhengzhou and will handle wheat transactions, the China Daily said Sunday. If the market is successful, the government may open futures markets for corn in the northeast city of Changchun, rice in the central city of Wuhan and pigs in southwest China's Sichuan province, the paper said. In the past, China has branded futures markets as a form of capitalist speculation. The nation's conservative leaders have stressed that market forces must play a subsidiary role in China's planned economy. A futures market allows traders and producers to negotiate a set price for a commodity at a given future date. The seller is guaranteed that price regardless of subsequent fluctuations in the market. Although most Chinese agricultural products must be sold to the state for a set price, an estimated 65 million tons of agricultural commodities circulate in the free market every year. Poor regulation of the free market has led to wild price fluctuations for produce and livestock and serious supply-demand gaps. The paper said foreign dealers will not be allowed to participate in the Zhengzhou market at the outset. But in February, the Chicago Board of Trade signed a memo of understanding in which it agreed to help the Chinese government set up futures markets.

DOC.HEAD: Co-Inventor of Semiconductor Chip Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to add Texas to dateline and CORRECT typo in lead; add background including Noyce quote, and Texas Industries quote. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Robert Noyce, who revolutionized electronics by co-inventing the semiconductor and later sought to revive American chip-making as head of the government-industry consortium Sematech, died Sunday of a heart attack. He was 62. Noyce suffered a heart attack at his Austin home Sunday morning and was pronounced dead minutes after his arrival at Seton Medical Center, hospital spokeswoman Elizabeth McDonald said. Working separately in the late 1950s, Noyce and Jack Kilby invented the integrated circuit, which made rapid gains in computer power possible by putting multiple transistors on a single chip. The Silicon Valley pioneer also was one of the founders of Intel Corp., the nation's third-largest semiconductor producer, and fought for the creation of a consortium to promote the American industry. ``He was really a legend within the electronics industry,'' spokesman Jim Jarrett said from Intel's Santa Clara, Calif. headquarters. ``He was always referred to as the mayor of Silicon Valley because he was such a respected and loved figure in the industry.'' ``Bob was an instrumental figure in creating what has become a $50 billion industry and semiconductors are the driving force behind a $500 billion electronics industry,'' said Stan Victor, a spokesman for Texas Instruments Inc. ``He will be missed.'' In 1988, Noyce was appointed as the first chief executive officer and president of Sematech, which was set up to help the United States recover world leadership in semiconductor manufacturing. That leadership was essential to the nation's economic and military security, he said, and American companies would have to adopt the cooperative practices of their Japanese competitors to regain it. After first taking himself out of the running for the job, Noyce said he accepted the post because ``it finally dawned on me it was far too important for someone else to do. I had to do it myself.'' The Austin-based consortium, which includes Intel, Texas Instruments and 12 other U.S. chip makers, has an annual budget of $200 million provided by the government and manufacturers. Sematech spokesman Joe Stroop said the consortium's management was deep enough to withstand Noyce's death. Noyce had asked Sematech's directors last April to begin a search for his eventual successor, Stroop said. Noyce did not said when he wanted to step down but ``had indicated he was willing to relinquish daily operational control,'' he said. Noyce had established a three-member management team consisting of himself, chief operating officer Turner E. Hasty and chief administrative officer Peter H. Mills, Stroop said. ``The office of chief executive will continue to function while we search for a successor,'' he said. ``There's a very solid infrastructure there and it should continue on with no problem,'' Intel's Jarrett said of the consortium. In addition to his Sematech duties, Noyce had retained his title as Intel's vice chairman and was an active member of the board of directors, Jarrett said. Noyce was born Dec. 12, 1927, in Burlington, Iowa. He was graduated from Grinnell College in Grinnell, Iowa, with bachelor's degrees in physics and mathematics and membership in Phi Beta Kappa. Noyce earned his Ph.D. in physics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1953. He became a researcher at Philco Corp., then later moved to the Shockley Semiconductor Laboratory. He co-founded Fairchild Semiconductor Corp. in 1957, where he and Kilby of Texas Instruments separately invented the integrated circuit. In 1968, Noyce and longtime associate Gordon E. Moore founded Intel Corp. Noyce was awarded the National Medal of Technology by President Reagan in 1987 and the National Medal of Science from President Carter in 1980. He was inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame in 1983 and elected to the U.S. Business Hall of Fame last year. In February, Noyce and Kilby were presented the first Charles Stark Draper Award by President Bush. ``Integrated circuits have enabled us to do the unimaginable,'' Bush said at the awards ceremony. ``Now, it is unimaginable to believe we could ever live without them. The microchip ... helped America change the world.'' Noyce held 16 patents for semiconductor devices, methods and structures. He was a founding member and first president of the Semiconductor Industry Association. He also was a member of the National Academy of Science, National Academy of Engineering and the American Academy of Arts and Science. Noyce is survived by his wife, Ann Bowers; four children and 12 grandchildren. Funeral arrangements were pending, according to Darryl Thompson of Weed-Corley Funeral Home.

DOC.HEAD: Captains Of U.S. Industry Meet For Visit With Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev pleaded with some of America's most prominent capitalists Sunday for their cooperation in reforming his country's sputtering economy. ``The important question is, `What kind of Soviet Union does the president and the U.S. people want to see?''' Gorbachev asked during a 90-minute session with businessmen at a hotel. ``A Soviet Union that is in turmoil, or a noble democratic state that is moving?'' He said the Soviet Union has spent the last five years sorting out ways to reform its centrally planned economy into one that is at least partly market-driven. Among other things, the Soviets will need help in changing decade-old management ideas, he said. ``The old system of running the economy has become weaker and the entire structure of the market economy is only beginning,'' he said. ``It is very difficult to abandon those old ways.'' The recent unveiling of an economic reform plan that called for a doubling of some food prices and the gradual privatization of some state enterprises triggered panic buying that left store shelves bare in some Soviet cities. Gorbachev said the Soviet economy is troubled because it is caught in a period of change. If economic reforms are successful, he said, civic unrest will end. ``When we begin such a project we feel we need American business because it is so big,'' Gorbachev said. The Soviet leader expressed gratitude for 150 joint business ventures now under way with companies in the U.S. The deals are improving Soviet efforts in food distribution, automation, medicine and farming, he said. American companies doing business in the Soviet Union will be rewarded with expanded business in the future, Gorbachev said. He warned that ``those who just stand on the sidelines who do not want to risk'' will remain on the sidelines when the Soviet economy is prospering. Gorbachev was welcomed to the hotel by Dwayne Andreas, chairman of Archer-Daniels-Midland Co., one of the United States' leading farm products companies. ``To me, Gorbachev is the man of the century,'' Andreas said. When Gorbachev's visit to Minnesota was first announced, Soviet organizers said the business meeting was his biggest priority. He was to take questions from the executives at the end of the session. The 145-name guest list included General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger Smith, International Business Machines Corp. Chairman John Akers, August Busch III of Anheuser-Busch Co., Roger Enrico of Pepsico, H. Lawrence Fuller of Amoco Corp., Frank Popoff of Dow Chemical Co. and Whitney MacMillan of Minnesota-based Cargill Inc., the private grain marketer that is the Soviet Union's largest private trading partner.
